headline: From Disney, a Video Game Universe on One Platform
abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

headline: In Heinz Takeover, a New Path for Deals
abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

headline: Tell Us: Employer Benefits for Same-Sex Couples
abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

headline: Goldman Overcomes Its Latest Headache
abstract: A case brought by the founders of Dragon Systems was among a spate of legal problems and public relations headaches for Goldman in recent years.

headline: Fund-Raising for Schools, Using Old Class Photos
abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Disappointing Super Bowl Ads, and a Hollywood Outsider Makes His Move
abstract: A critique of the Super Bowl ads finds them wanting; Legendary Entertainment, run by a Hollywood outsider, gets a large piece of the blockbuster movie season; and the FX channel embraces the dark side of storytelling.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: What’s New in TVs
abstract: David Pogue walks the floor of the International Consumer Electronics Show and finds humor in the excess — mostly of it unintended by the companies.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: Industry Shifts With Dell Deal
abstract: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: After Staff Reductions, New Appointments at The Times
abstract: The masthead has been restructured as part of the changes, Jill Abramson, the executive editor, said in a memo to the staff.

headline: Thursday Reading: The Low-Rise-Jeans Insanity Defense
abstract: The low-rise-jeans insanity defense, new evidence for cellphone distractions, F.D.A. to ease rules on Alzheimer’s drugs and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Yahoo-Google Deal and Ladies’ Laptop Bags
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include an analysis of a deals to make Beats by Dre headphones, Facebook and European officials resolving a dispute over facial recognition data and a new agreement between yahoo and Google.

headline: Jacob Lew, Mary Jo White and Dunbar’s Number
abstract: It is important for the president’s nominees to head the Treasury and the Securities and Exchange Commission to have sufficient ties outside banking circles, an economist writes.

headline: A Start-Up Aims to Upend E-Commerce by Selling Nail Polish
abstract: Julep, a nail polish e-commerce company started by a former Starbucks executive, has attracted attention from top venture capitalists.

headline: Sears and Penney Respond to ‘SNL’ Sketch Complaint
abstract: The companies have made arrangements to avoid placing any ads adjacent to online replays of the sketch in question, but that will not affect any commercials in the television version of “SNL.”

headline: At Davos, Hunting for the Next Big Thing….uh, Country
abstract: As Brazil and Argentina lose some of their luster, are sub-Saharan African nations on the rise? Billionaire dealmakers want to know.

headline: Pfizer Spins Off Animal Health Unit in $2.2 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: The Pfizer division, known as Zoetis, exceeded expectations by pricing its stock at $26 a share in an initial public offering that values the company at about $13 billion.

headline: Europe’s Reaction to Italian Elections: ‘Devastating’ ‘Chaos’
abstract: The European press went into overdrive on Tuesday with a shocked response to the political gridlock in Italy and the potential spillover to the euro zone. Are the doom-mongers justified, or is the indecisive outcome just a historical blip?

headline: Eliot Spitzer Ends His Show on Current TV
abstract: His decision to leave the channel comes a few days after Al Jazeera took control of Current TV. Later this year, the Qatar-owned broadcaster plans to turn the channel into an Americanized version of the international news channel Al Jazeera English.

headline: Indian Government Gets Support From Unlikely Corner
abstract: All India Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee supports government on Sri Lanka.

headline: War on the Heels of a Wedding
abstract: Rebekah Sanderlin, an Army wife, recounts the start of the war in Iraq as a new bride.

headline: Five Questions for: Aminatta Forna
abstract: The 2011 Commonwealth Writers’ Prize winner on her writing rituals, including a special mug.

headline: Controversial Media Deal in Taiwan Nears Collapse
abstract: The pro-Beijing businessmen seeking to buy two liberal publications in Taiwan were unlikely to meet a deadline on Wednesday to complete the sale, a spokesman said.

headline: ‘Smash’ Premiere Falls Short, Loses Viewers
abstract: The show, which was extensively retooled by NBC after a disappointing season, fell a staggering 71 percent in viewership from its opening episode last season.

headline: China Hints at Far Wider Welcome to Overseas Investors
abstract: Foreign participation in mainland stock markets could increase tenfold, said Guo Shuqing, the country’s top securities regulator.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: Changes at The New Republic
abstract: The right to unlock cellphones expires. Chris Hughes, publisher of The New Republic, discusses its redesign. An animated look at how technology may change our daily routines.

headline: False Modesty in Decline in European Bank Bonuses
abstract: One might have expected European bank bosses to show more contrition in the year that the Libor scandal erupted, the author writes.

headline: J.C. Penney’s Poor Showing Is Another Retail Miss for Ackman
abstract: With J.C. Penney’s awful fourth-quarter results, William A. Ackman has once more found success in retail investments elusive.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Is Said to Scrutinize Microsoft Accusations
abstract: The S.E.C. and the Justice Department are said to be investigating Microsoft’s involvement with companies accused of paying bribes overseas, Nick Wingfield reports in Wednesday’s New York Times.

headline: HSBC Adds to Oversight Effort With Board Committee
abstract: HSBC has created a new board committee to improve oversight, appointing five independent advisers to work with the group of directors.

headline: Amid a Shake-Up, JPMorgan’s Risk Officer Takes a Leave
abstract: JPMorgan Chase’s chief risk officer is taking a temporary sabbatical, the latest move in an extensive reshuffling of JPMorgan’s executive suite after a botched credit bet that has cost the bank more than $6 billion.

headline: ‘Jekyll and Hyde’ Musical May Become a Movie
abstract: As the movie “Les Misérables” garners attention, a partnership has bought the film rights to the musical inspired by the Robert Louis Stevenson novella.

headline: Fate of Herbalife’s Stock May Lie With Government Agencies
abstract: The actions of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission may have more influence over the direction of Herbalife’s stock price than two hedge fund managers do.

headline: Lively Online Reactions in China to Nuclear Test
abstract: Chinese netizens reacted mostly critically, in tens of thousands of posts, to the nuclear test by North Korea, its neighbor with which it shares good relations. But some were supportive.

headline: Sony Makes Deal for Electronic Dance Music
abstract: The deal is the latest sign of the music industry’s rush to embrace electronic dance, and significantly raises the profile of Ultra, which had already become a force in that genre.

headline: Filling the Pews: Challenges for the New Pope
abstract: Roman Catholics around the world share their views on the leadership of the church, and Daniel J. Wakin reports from Rome.

headline: Comparing Asia’s Giants, China and India, on Rape
abstract: In today’s Female Factor Letter I explore rape in China and India, two Asian giants that more often are compared on population size and economic growth.

headline: Warner to Show 3-D Film Trailers at Truck Stops
abstract: To advertise the 3-D effects of “Jack the Giant Slayer,” the studio is buying space on Travel Plaza TV, distributed in about 300 gas stations and Pilot Flying J truck stops in 42 states.

headline: Campus Banking Practices Come Under Scrutiny
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is seeking information about bank accounts and debit cards marketed to students by colleges and universities.

headline: Christie Gets His Chance for Revenge on Letterman
abstract: The “Late Night” host has produced a continuing stream of jokes about the New Jersey governor’s weight. On Monday night, Mr. Christie will appear on the show for the first time.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘The Bachelor’ Draws Viewers, and Martha Stewart’s Need for Privacy
abstract: “The Bachelor” regains high ratings, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia might be better off private and copyright issues have arisen for “Harlem Shake.”

headline: TimesCast: An Interview with Andrew Sullivan
abstract: The editor and founder of The Dish discusses how his readers, and not advertisers, are financing his newly independent blog.

headline: Facebook News Feed Draws More Criticism
abstract: While Facebook responded to criticism that it was suppressing content in its news feed in order to highlight advertising posts, small businesses started voicing concerns about the company’s actions too.

headline: New Chief of Royal Opera Is a Manager, Not an Artist
abstract: The new chief executive of the Royal Opera House is Alex Beard, the deputy director of the four Tate museums.

headline: In India, ‘One Billion Rising’ Resonates With Many
abstract: The issue of violence against women has dominated public discussion for weeks.

headline: How to Beat Some Facebook Scammers
abstract: There is a thriving business in artificially inflating a Facebook page’s audience. Here is one way scammers trick you into helping them, and what you can do to stop it.

headline: An Argentine Parallel
abstract: Preferring some creditors over others is at issue in the Argentine debt litigation. Yet, a similar idea is being suggested by some House Republicans.

headline: Soft-Drink Giant Wants Consumers to Be ‘Impressed’
abstract: This week, the Dr Pepper Snapple Group will proclaim that the Olympian McKayla Maroney has finally found something that impresses her: five new soft drinks that are entries in the lower-calorie category of the carbonated-beverage market.

headline: India Posts Optimistic Economic Projections Despite Slowdown
abstract: An improving global economy will boost India’s growth, government predicts.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include a Kickstarter campaign seeking $30,000 to make men’s socks, a guide for talking about Sheryl Sandberg’s book without reading it and Grumpy Cat live at the SXSW conference.

headline: Live Blog: Senate Panel on JPMorgan’s Trading Loss
abstract: A Senate subcommittee questioned bank executives and regulators in a hearing today.

headline: The Risks of Expanding Into Australia
abstract: Opening in a new country presents an opportunity for growth and revenue, but it is also an opportunity to lose ours shirts.

headline: F.B.I. File on Times Publisher Was Destroyed Before His Death
abstract: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the Times publisher during whose long tenure the Pentagon Papers were published, had drawn the attention of federal investigators.

headline: Why an I.P.O. Revival May Have to Wait
abstract: Yes, there have been pickups in a number of debt markets, but equities issuance still faces challenges, the author notes.

headline: Q&A: Fixing Flash Player Settings
abstract: If a Facebook game will not work properly in the Firefox browser, check the settings for the Adobe Flash Player software that works with the browser.

headline: Where Does Your Hurricane Sandy Claim Stand?
abstract: Bucks readers tell of their own experiences in dealing with their insurance companies for damage to their homes from Hurricane Sandy.

headline: AT&T Will Buy Some Verizon Spectrum for $1.9 Billion
abstract: AT&T has agreed to buy some spectrum — the radio waves that carry wireless calls and data — from its main competitor, Verizon Wireless. It will pay $1.9 billion for spectrum licenses that would cover 42 million people across 18 states.

headline: NBC Shuts Down Hyperlocal Web Site
abstract: EveryBlock, a pioneering Web site for hyperlocal data-driven journalism, shut down on Thursday, disappointing longtime fans.

headline: Q and A: Keeping ‘A Chorus Line’ in Step
abstract: Bob Avian, who was one of the original choreographers of “A Chorus Line” and who has been overseeing the major revivals of the show since, talks about the challenges and rewards of the latest version, now on stage at the London Palladium.

headline: U.S. Contends S.& P. Purposely Used Faulty Models
abstract: The Justice Department’s suit against Standard & Poor’s over mortgage-related securities says computer programs assessing risk were manipulated to ensure high ratings and big profits.

headline: Horsemeat Scandal Grows More Serious and More Bizarre
abstract: From a modest proposal by some German politicians that the poor eat the suspect horsemeat products to the tainting of the iconic Ikea Swedish meatball, is nothing sacred?

headline: Glass Lewis Urges MetroPCS Investors to Reject T-Mobile Deal
abstract: The firm joined its larger rival, Institutional Shareholder Services, in casting aspersions on the transaction, raising pressure on MetroPCS and T-Mobile to sweeten the terms of the merger or risk defeat.

headline: Why Cyprus Will Pay Dearly
abstract: There are no good alternatives, the author contends. But the longer it takes for Cyprus to recognize how bleak its situation is, the greater the damage.

headline: Are Immigrants Taking Your Job? A Primer
abstract: There are a lot of competing studies (and pundits), but the general takeaway from conservative and liberal economists is that immigration is good for native workers’ living standards over the long run.

headline: A Conversation With: Economist and Author Vivek Dehejia
abstract: On his first book, “Indianomix,” and why things happen the way they do in India.

headline: Just Business: 2 Hedge Fund Rivals Clash Over Herbalife
abstract: Daniel Loeb, the Third Point chief, and William A. Ackman are locked in a battle over, of all things, a nutritional supplements company that makes protein bars and energy shakes.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Liberty Global Buys Virgin Media and How to Talk About “House of Cards,” Sans Spoilers
abstract: Liberty Global is buying Virgin Media for about $16 billion, spoiler concerns after the simultaneous release of all 13 episodes of “House of Cards” on Netflix, and the Church of Scientology’s Super Bowl ad.

headline: Google’s Antitrust Victory
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission found that Google had not violated antitrust statutes in the way it structures its Web search application.

headline: Tip of the Week: How to Control the Music in iTunes 11
abstract: If the full iTunes 11 window takes up too much screen space, you can shrink it down and still control the music.

headline: Market Milestones Can Lead to False Assumptions
abstract: When the stock market hits new highs or lows, investors often question whether they should be making changes to their original investment plan.

headline: Farming a Beach
abstract: Nothing but sand and pebbles where there once were fertile fields on a Brahmaputra River tributary.

headline: Led by Celebrity Titles, Magazine Newsstand Sales Slide
abstract: People, US Weekly, Cosmopolitan and Glamour all suffered double-digit decreases in the second half of 2012.

headline: The Fitbit Flex Improves on Its Rivals
abstract: At the Consumer Electronics Show, FitBit flashed the features of the FitBit Flex. It’s a silicone bracelet just like the Up and Nike bands, but with neither of the drawbacks — it does track sleep and it does use energy-saving Bluetooth 4.0.

headline: Michael Dell’s Empire in a Buyout Spotlight
abstract: The computer mogul Michael Dell, in talks to acquire the company he started as a teenager, has built a reputation as a shrewd investor.

headline: A Conversation With: U.S.A.I.D. Administrator Rajiv Shah
abstract: The American agency has changed its approach to aid in India completely.

headline: Uber to Roll Out Ride Sharing in California
abstract: Californians who don’t want to drive will soon have more ways to hire a ride. Uber, a start-up company that offers a smartphone app for summoning cars, is expanding its service to support ride-sharing so ordinary citizens can drive people around in exchange for money.

headline: Does the ‘House of Cards’ All-You-Can-Eat Buffet Spoil Social Viewing?
abstract: The great thing about Netflix’s “House of Cards”? You can watch it all at once. That may be the bad thing, too. How do you gather around a water cooler and talk about a moving target?

headline: The Smartphone Frontiers: India, Russia, Brazil
abstract: Here in the United States, if you whip out a clamshell flip phone, you’ll almost immediately be called a caveman or Luddite. But in some emerging countries, the old-school cellphone has yet to become passé.

headline: Prophecies Made in Davos Don’t Always Come True
abstract: Many influential people will gather this week at the World Economic Forum to make predictions, and some of them will be right, and some wrong.

headline: Groupon C.E.O. Is Out
abstract: Andrew Mason, the irreverent chief executive of Groupon, was ousted on Thursday. | Richard Schulze’s effort to take over Best Buy, the company he founded, has fallen apart. | Lanny A. Breuer, who spent four years running the Justice Department’s criminal division, is leaving his post on Friday. | One of Citigroup’s internal hedge funds is beginning a new life on Friday as an independent firm.

headline: Down With Guy Fawkes!
abstract: Bahrain has banned Guy Fawkes masks as part of a crackdown on pro-democracy protests. The move is only likely to enhance the worldwide popularity of the must-have protest accessory. But is Fawkes really a good role model?

headline: Icahn Gains 2 Seats on Herbalife’s Board
abstract: Herbalife plans to give two board seats to Carl C. Icahn, as the health supplements maker further binds itself to its most outspoken outside defender of late.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Your Disney Questions Answered
abstract: Your Disney questions answered, you can learn to be a butcher, W-2 forms list employer cost of health plans and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: A Doll Helps Disabled Women Find Their Voices
abstract: Women with learning disabilities are especially vulnerable to sex abuse. The Josephine Project is helping educate such women and raising awareness of the issue.

headline: Five Arrested in Gang Rape of Swiss Tourist in Central India
abstract: The woman, 39, was on a cycling tour with her husband when they were attacked.

headline: The Difficult Choices Ahead for the Dell Board
abstract: The bids, for now, are placeholders. And even if all of the hoops are jumped through and the Dell board finds a Blackstone bid or Icahn final bid to be superior, the Silver Lake group has matching rights under the merger agreement.

headline: Malone’s Minority Report
abstract: The cable pioneer John C. Malone has a history of parlaying minority stakes in companies into advantageous deals for himself.

headline: Can Armstrong Be Redeemed? How About Galliano?
abstract: John Galliano, the disgraced British fashion designer, is making a tentative return after his racist tirade. Lance Armstrong, the fallen cyclist, sat down with Oprah Winfrey to confess, in part to prepare his comeback. Will the public forgive and forget?

abstract: Will appear in a fast-track court for corruption.

abstract: The state has reported a drastic decrease in the number of Maoist-related deaths since Mamata Banerjee took over.

headline: Money Requested for New Prison at Guantánamo
abstract: The United States Southern Command has requested $49 million to build a new prison building for “special” detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on top of other renovations it says are necessary since Congress has decided to keep it open indefinitely.

abstract: Cyprus secures a bailout deal. | Banks lose a loophole | An F.C.C. shift may thwart a Murdoch media deal. | Buyers Circle Marks & Spencer as takeover target | A buyer is found for Blockbuster’s British unit.

abstract: Companies, universities and lawmakers in the United States are preparing for a world in which remote-controlled planes will be ubiquitous in civilian air space.

headline: A New Home, and a New App, for San Francisco’s Exploratorium
abstract: The Exploratorium, the hands-on science museum in San Francisco, will open its doors in April at its new location at Pier 15 on the waterfront. On Monday, though, its second free iPad application will be available in Apple’s app store.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 15
abstract: Islamists gain ground in Mali; Chinese censors in Los Angeles; another Washington showdown looms; men’s wear in Milan.

headline: Waiting for War, and Working to Fit In
abstract: A general assignment reporter from Manhattan, Michael Wilson worked hard to fit in among the Marine officers in Kuwait and Iraq.

headline: A Push to Investigate North Korea’s Human Rights Abuses
abstract: As ties between China and North Korea wobble and perhaps cool, Pyongyang may be facing a United Nations inquiry into possible crimes against humanity.

headline: Hungarian Leader Takes Right-wing Defiance to Brussels
abstract: Prime Minister Viktor Orban is skipping Revolution Day in Hungary to confront his E.U. critics who see his constitutional changes as a trampling of liberty.

headline: A Random Gift of Coffee Makes My Day
abstract: A kindness movement advocates surprising strangers with small gifts or nice behavior.

headline: Carlyle’s Profit Fell in 4th Quarter as Growth Slowed
abstract: The Carlyle Group said on Thursday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 28 percent from the period a year earlier, as the growth of its portfolio companies slowed.

headline: Group Seeks Out and Helps Homeless Veterans
abstract: The mission of the Vet Hunters Project is to track down homeless veterans and offer aid.

headline: Armstrong Confession Draws 4.3 Million Viewers to Oprah’s Network
abstract: The result was a far cry from some of Ms. Winfrey’s most famous interviews, as some viewers struggled to find OWN on their television.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: For Sony, the More Pixels the Better
abstract: Sony, the struggling Japanese electronics company, is trying hard to get your attention. It can’t resist highlighting big numbers for the features inside its products. The company introduced its newest Android phone, the Xperia Z, which has a 13-megapixel camera, along with two Ultra High-Definition TVs.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 4
abstract: A victory for Google; China’s evolving approach to AIDS; Al Jazeera’s new bid for American viewers; Gérard Depardieu, Russian star.

abstract: The same critics that assailed the government’s role in the boom and bust in the housing market are attacking the Federal Housing Administration for its lending standards.

abstract: Schools reopen in the Kashmir valley after a long winter break.

abstract: A reversal on a shareholder rights issue would be a bitter pill to swallow for Deutsche Bank’s co-chief executives, Anshu Jain and Jürgen Fitschen. But there are good reason for one, and the timing looks propitious, the author writes.

headline: Mozilla Builds an Operating System for a Firefox Smartphone
abstract: Mozilla, which created the Firefox browser, is coming out with a smartphone that costs less than one-fifth the price of an iPhone that is aimed at the developing world.

headline: An Italian Bank’s Murky Scandal
abstract: It is still not clear whether the Bank of Italy, Deutsche Bank and Nomura could have been more vigorous in pursuing hints that things were not quite right at Monte dei Paschi di Siena.

headline: The Case for Shaking Up Hewlett’s Board
abstract: Replacing several directors responsible for H.P.’s past missteps would bring some accountability to the board and ensure an uncomfortable breakup of the company is not pushed aside, the writer contends.

abstract: E-mail messages that claim to be from the Internal Revenue Service asking for personal information are probably phishing scams.

abstract: Kathakali dancers from Kerala perform during a roadshow in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Fandango Creates a Movie Buzz Index
abstract: Fanticipation, from Fandango, the online seller of movie tickets, will rank upcoming releases based on a formula that includes social media data and advance ticket sales

abstract: The papal election; Syria’s bitterly personal war; pig carcasses and the food supply in China; European leaders insist on austerity; and a new show from an all-male dance company.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The Tech Industry Looks to Online Gambling and Business Insider Appoints an Executive Editor
abstract: The technology industry has set its sights on online gambling, Business Insider names Joe Weisenthal as executive editor and authenticating an online photo in Omaha takes more shoe leather than tech savvy.

abstract: The primary sticking point between the two companies was the fate of several titles, including Time and Sports Illustrated, which Time Warner wanted to shed but which Meredith was not eager to acquire.

headline: Hopper Show Pulls Some All-Nighters
abstract: In Paris this weekend, a chance to see “Nighthawks” at night.

headline: What, No Trishna’s?
abstract: A list of the 50 best restaurants in Asia leaves out some Indian favorites.

headline: Goldman Retreats From Plan to Award Bonuses Later in Britain
abstract: Goldman Sachs decided Tuesday it would not delay the payment of bonuses to its staff in Britain, a move that would have helped investment bankers and other top employees to benefit from a lower income tax rate.

headline: Pressures Mount on European Media
abstract: What can be done to preserve the independence of the European media and ensure competition?

headline: Time for an Asian Pope?
abstract: The Catholic Church chooses a new pope soon. With the church in a stronger position in Latin America, Africa and parts of Asia than in Europe and North America, there are calls for a Pope from one of these places.

headline: S.E.C. Names New Top Lawyer
abstract: Geoffrey F. Aronow, a partner in the Washington office of Bingham McCutchen and a former head of enforcement for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, will be general counsel of the S.E.C.

headline: Canada Pension Plan Unit to Join K.K.R. Merchant Banking Venture
abstract: An arm of the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board said on Thursday that it would be the latest partner in a merchant banking business run by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Do You Listen to Your Employees?
abstract: It’s amazing what you can find out when you ask questions instead of making assumptions.

headline: The New Rules for Reporting Stock Sales
abstract: Bucks readers discuss their experience with a new rule that requires their brokerage firms to report to the I.R.S. the price they paid for certain taxable investments.

headline: Samsung Is Forming an Army in Barcelona
abstract: Samsung Electronics had no new phone to show at Mobile World Congress this week. But the company’s presence dominated the show nonetheless, as it sought partnerships to help its pursuit of Apple.

headline: You Have Identified the Candidates. How Do You Pick the Right One?
abstract: When we started H.Bloom, we would hire a candidate based exclusively on e-mail interactions, a phone screen and in-person interviews. After a couple of early mistakes, we realized that we needed to make a change.

abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

abstract: A case brought by the founders of Dragon Systems was among a spate of legal problems and public relations headaches for Goldman in recent years.

abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.

abstract: David Pogue walks the floor of the International Consumer Electronics Show and finds humor in the excess — mostly of it unintended by the companies.

abstract: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: It’s Davos Time Again
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin says Davos predictions don’t always come true and Alison Smale, the executive editor of the IHT, points out that crisis is the new normal. All amid a growing sense at Davos that bankers have suffered enough “abuse.”

headline: Illumina Buys Maker of Down Syndrome Test
abstract: Amid a report that Roche is no longer interested in a takeover, Illumina makes a deal of its own, in a sign that DNA sequencing is now moving toward being used for medical diagnosis.

headline: The Limits of U.S. Aid to Rebels in Syria
abstract: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, speaks with correspondent Mark Landler on the White House’s deliberations on what kind of aid to give forces fighting Bashar al-Assad, and how.

headline: Egan-Jones Barred for 18 Months on Some Ratings
abstract: The agreement settles accusations that the firm made misstatements about its record when applying for a government designation, the S.E.C. said.

headline: Bertelsmann Acquires Full Control of BMG Music Company
abstract: Bertelsmann restarted BMG in 2008, and now has bought up the 51 percent stake owned by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, signaling a full return to the music business.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Long-form articles on what’s wrong with India’s juvenile justice system and the authenticity of sex surveys conducted in India.

headline: Why Vodafone Should Head for a Verizon Exit
abstract: Vodafone’s stake in Verizon Wireless may be worth $120 billion. If a deal can be reached with Verizon, the big question is what strategic options the British telecommunications would pursue with such a windfall.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Cable Lifts Earnings at Time Warner and News Corp. and the Surprise Seller of a Malibu Mansion
abstract: Strong cable television gains prove a boon for Time Warner and News Corp, the owner of a rather gaudy $25 million home that hit the market in Malibu may surprise you and Melena Ryzik chats with Steven Spielberg about the difficulties of filming “Lincoln.”

headline: Dell Shares Rise on News Company May Go Private
abstract: The struggling computer maker needs to revamp, and a sale to private equity would allow big changes without having to keep shareholders happy.

headline: Spotify, New to Advertising, Says ‘I’ve Got the Music in Me’
abstract: The major competitors in digital music services are spending large sums on advertising campaigns that are meant to generate awareness, consideration and trial. The newest entrant in the ad club is Spotify, which plans on Monday to start its first campaign aimed at American music lovers.

headline: Campaign Promotes New Bank Service for N.B.A. Fans
abstract: BBVA Compass, the American franchise of the Spanish bank, and the NBA will unveil a campaign on Friday to promote online consumer checking and savings accounts.

headline: Monday Reading: Drowsy Drivers Pose Major Risks
abstract: Drowsy drivers pose major risks, health insurers raise some premiums by double digits, plenty of room on Maine’s ski slopes and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: S.&P. Lawsuit Draws New Line in the Sand
abstract: The government’s lawsuit against Standard & Poor’s over credit ratings suggests that we may see fewer settlements and more court cases involving financial institutions in the future.

headline: Ieng Sary, Dead Before Justice Is Done
abstract: Cambodia’s genocide court faces a challenge as the elderly former leaders of the Khmer Rouge defendants are hospitalized, declared mentally unfit or die, delaying justice, perhaps forever.

headline: The New Beltway Icebreaker: “What Episode of ‘House of Cards’ Are You On?”
abstract: “House of Cards” has become the new D.C. social crutch, a pick-up line of sorts that guarantees ready-made conversation.

headline: Mumbai’s ‘Focus’ Festival Showcases Women Photographers
abstract: Work by Indian and international female photographers deals with free speech and emancipation.

headline: The Sequester and Fiscal Policy
abstract: The sequester and the across-the-board spending cuts it brings are almost the exact opposite of what the economy needs to grow and create jobs, an economist writes.

headline: RHA Earphones Cut Frills and the Price
abstract: RHA, which makes some good-quality earphones at a modest price, has adapted some key components from its higher-end earphones to produce the budget-price MA150.

headline: Most Facebook Users Have Taken a Break From the Site, Survey Finds
abstract: A new survey from Pew Internet, a research center, found that a majority of Facebook users took voluntary breaks from the site, citing boredom or concerns about privacy.

headline: National Book Awards to Diversify Judging Pool
abstract: Seeking to increase the awards’ relevance and profile, the National Book Foundation is adding to the number of finalists and expanding the list of judges beyond writers, to potentially include critics, librarians and booksellers.

abstract: The New York Times’s David Gillen on new findings against JPMorgan Chase, and Louise Story talks to Thomas Hoenig of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, who says banks are too big to manage.

headline: Private Equity and Venture Capital Investments Rise in Latin America
abstract: Private equity and venture capital firms last year committed $7.9 billion to invest in Latin America, although fund-raising was down significantly as smaller firms raised more than big firms.

headline: The Clinton Doctrine of American Foreign Policy
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s time as secretary of state saw no major breakthroughs and few mistakes, but as she left she made the case for a new American foreign policy.

headline: Staying Ahead of the Tax Man
abstract: Personal income in December jumped drastically thanks to dividends, bonuses and other income moving into 2012 ahead of higher tax rates scheduled for 2013.

headline: A Deal-Making Craze? Yes, With Caveats
abstract: The deals of recent weeks have very little to do with the trends that bankers on Wall Street say they believe will drive a new cycle of deal-making.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The ‘Today’ Show’s Popularity Woes, and Anxiety at Time Inc.
abstract: NBC’s “Today” show faces dwindling popularity, perhaps because of Matt Lauer; Time Inc. employees are worried about the company’s prospects after it is spun off; and some new Spanish media outlets are trying to look on the bright side.

headline: In the Tracking Wars, It’s Browser Makers vs. Advertisers
abstract: Apple, Microsoft and now Mozilla offer browser users varying ways to block tracking cookies, sending a signal to advertisers that consumer privacy is important to their business models.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Murdoch Weighs a Newspaper Deal and Steve Harvey Surprises Daytime TV
abstract: Rupert Murdoch will have to wrangle with regulators once again if he tries to buy The Los Angeles Times, Steve Harvey has become a daytime TV standout and NBC is risking one of its rare high points in the ratings by replacing Jay Leno on “Tonight” with Jimmy Fallon.

headline: France Rethinks Its No-School-on-Wednesdays Week
abstract: Primary school teachers in Paris are on strike, protesting a plan by the new French government to modify the school rhythm for the country’s youngest pupils. How is the school week organized in your country? Do you think shorter days and longer weeks are more conducive to learning, or do schoolchildren benefit from having a midweek break?

headline: Tracking Cicadas, With Helpers
abstract: “Radiolab” has scheduled Cicada Tracker Maker events to help people build sensors that will detect the temperatures that herald the emergence of cicadas.

headline: Studios Have Differing Responses to Visual Effects Company’s Financial Woes
abstract: Two studios that are supplied by the company, called Rhythm and Hues, are extending credit, but a third, Warner Brothers, is not.

headline: Regulators and 13 Banks Complete $9.3 Billion Deal for Foreclosure Relief
abstract: The settlement was reached amid heightened concerns that a foreclosure review process was generating billions of dollars in fees for consultants, but providing little relief for borrowers.

headline: Tip of the Week: Free Microsoft Office Quick-Start Guides
abstract: Microsoft has free colorful guides to the new features in its Office 2013 suite, available to download from its site.

headline: An Ambitious Woman From a Delhi Neighborhood of Migrants
abstract: Friends, acquaintances and neighbors remember a young woman who has become a symbol for India’s youth.

headline: A Call for a National Strategy on Veterans
abstract: A National Veterans Strategy would include a national dialogue to define our societal obligations to those who volunteer for military service and establishing policies to carry out those obligations, engaging government, the private sector, veterans service organizations and local communities to combine resources in support of veterans and their families.

headline: Do People Actually Shop on Phones? The Answer Is Decidedly Yes
abstract: Mobile devices have clearly changed the way people shop. In 2012, consumers spent $25 billion, or 11 percent of e-commerce dollars, while shopping on mobile devices, particularly tablets, according to data from eMarketer.

headline: Deep Cuts Raise Questions About Morgan Stanley
abstract: Morgan Stanley has been shrinking its business of trading bonds, commodities and other investments, leaving that to be dominated by its Wall Street rivals.

abstract: Morgan Stanley reported adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on Friday, driven by gains in wealth management and investment banking.

abstract: Ms. O’Brien said Thursday that she will leave CNN’s morning show in the spring and form a production company to supply documentaries to CNN on a nonexclusive basis.

abstract: The litigation challenging the orderly liquidation authority under the Dodd-Frank Act proceeds from the faulty notion that Chapter 11 bankruptcy provides a one-size-fits-all solution,

headline: A Technical Debate With Broader Implications for Deal-Making
abstract: The emerging issue of “don’t ask/don’t waive” standstills is a debate that only a Delaware deals lawyer could love. But it has the potential to change the way that public companies are sold.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 2
abstract: Concern about ivory trade; joblessness rises in Europe; challenge for Syrian rebel leader; and Swiss consider compensation laws.

headline: Marvel Signs Agreement to Take Superheroes on the Road
abstract: Feld Entertainment, which produces Disney on Ice and other touring shows, will introduce a road show featuring Spider-Man and other Marvel superheroes in summer 2014.

headline: Report Details Missteps in Trading at JPMorgan
abstract: An internal report written by a management task force pointed to widespread failures regarding a bad bet on credit derivatives that cost JPMorgan Chase more than $6 billion.

headline: Ayasdi: A Big Data Start-Up With a Long History
abstract: Ayasdi, a Big Data start-up, is based on years of mathematical research led by Gunnar Carlsson, a Stanford professor. The company says its technology allows users to see significant patterns in large business and scientific data sets without having to know what questions to ask.

headline: Depardieu vs. Beckham: Is France Gaining or Losing?
abstract: The moves are not related, as far as we know, but the arrival of David Beckham in France may be seen by some as restoring the country’s honor among millionaires — only Beckham will make London home..

headline: Russian Military Ordered to Switch to Socks
abstract: Cloth strips, called portyanki, have been a signature element of the Russian military uniform since the 16th century. On Monday, Russia’s minister of defense issued an order for soldiers to switch to socks.

headline: Four Years Later, 28,000 More Jobs
abstract: It appears that the past four years had a net gain of just 28,000 jobs. Private-sector jobs were up, but government employment was down.

abstract: James E. Staley, a longtime JPMorgan Chase executive who served as the firm’s head of investment banking until a management shake-up last year, is leaving the bank to join the hedge fund BlueMountain Capital Management as a managing partner.

headline: Selling a Business? It’s the Details That Count
abstract: While the mistakes made by this business seller are easy to spot in retrospect, it’s also easy to understand how sellers fall into these traps.

headline: India to Investigate Corruption in Italian Copter Deal
abstract: Indian government signed a $747.4 deal with a subsidiary of aerospace company Finmeccanica in 2010.

abstract: An anti-Semitism watchdog has provoked a storm by including a prominent German journalist in a list of leading anti-Semites. His defenders insist criticism of Israel does not equate with hatred of Jews.

headline: Image of the Day: March 26
abstract: Festival of Panguni Uthiram being celebrated in Chennai, Tamil Nadu.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Ugly Photos, and Delivery by Google
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. headline: History Shadows an Upbeat Music Sales Forecast
abstract: For those who have seen the industry’s optimism dashed before, an upbeat report on Tuesday by its global trade body, the International Federation for the Phonographic Industry, brought hope and skepticism.

abstract: Hostess Brands is near a deal to name a pair of private equity firms as the collective lead bidder for its Twinkies brand, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

abstract: Faced with international regulations that go easy on the big banks, the United States should develop its own tighter rules and be prepared to implement them alone, an economist writes.

abstract: The British bank HSBC said that it had completed the sale of its entire 15.6 percent stake in the Ping An Insurance Group to the Charoen Pokphand Group of Thailand for $9.4 billion, despite previous concerns about the buyer’s financing.

headline: Smoother Access to Europe for the Trusted Few
abstract: A proposed new border regime has been billed as offering an open and secure Europe. Critics say it is just a way to make life harder for the kind of visitors the Continent does not really want.

headline: India’s Man Problem
abstract: Millions of “extra” young men, thanks to decades of female foeticide, mean a rise in violence against women, some argue.

headline: News Corp. Posts Gain on Strength of Cable Channels
abstract: On Wednesday, the company reported net income of $2.38 billion, or $1.01 a share, compared with $1.06 billion, or $0.42 a share in the same three-month period a year earlier.

headline: Telemarketer That Aimed at  the Elderly Is Shut Down
abstract: The firm tried to trick elderly people into paying for medical alert services they didn’t order.

headline: Best Metros in the World:  Hong Kong, Bangalore, Tashkent …
abstract: When Rendezvous asked readers about their favorite metro, we received hundreds of impassioned responses. Public transport, and especially its failings, can spark quite a debate.

headline: Why Are Small Businesses Less Optimistic Than Big Ones?
abstract: For one thing, big businesses have a larger global footprint, which gives them greater exposure to growth in places like China and Brazil.

abstract: Jeffrey Zucker, the head of CNN, named Kate Bolduan the co-host of CNN’s forthcoming morning show with Chris Cuomo.

abstract: Yingluck Shinawatra says that despite reports to the contrary, she, and not her brother, runs Thailand.

abstract: The issues being investigated range from prior knowledge of the Madoff scam to inadequate prevention of money-laundering.

headline: Interpreters’ Accomplishments Fail to Translate Into Visas
abstract: On the battlefield, individuals with language skills are rare and highly prized. Once their job is done, however, they do not always receive much protection from the militaries they serve.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Frugal Gangnam Style in Seoul
abstract: Frugal Gangnam style in Seoul, travel sites jump to the iPad, Lexus ranks No. 1 on the Consumer Reports scorecard and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: CNN prevailed among the main cable news networks for ratings covering President Obama’s speech, in the daytime, as well as evening coverage of the inaugural balls. But ratings overall were way down from 2009.

abstract: Thousands including women and children demand action against the rising pollution in the river.

abstract: The channel has bought the rights to the best seller by Bill O’Reilly for a production headed by Ridley Scott. It will also show Mr. O’Reilly’s other best seller, “Killing Lincoln.”

abstract: While financial advisers at other firms are typically free to offer a variety of investments, JPMorgan pressures brokers to sell the bank’s own products, current and former employees say.

abstract: When using the photo app EyeEm on Facebook, tend to your privacy settings carefully or it will automatically share not only the photos you take, but also the photos you view.

abstract: BuzzFeed, the social news Web site that was one of the media industry darlings of 2012, said Thursday that it had raised nearly $20 million in new financing from its investors.

abstract: If you do not like the way a photo preview appears on your Facebook Timeline page, you can change it.

abstract: Mr.Chamling on the state’s development mantra, high growth rate and 18 years in office.

abstract: A straightforward spot demonstrating the capacity of a French-door refrigerator from Samsung received the highest score for any of the almost 6,000 commercials that Ace Metrix evaluated last year.

abstract: On a typical campaign, the company spends more than $10,000 a month on Google ads that it believes end up more than paying for themselves.

abstract: After several delays and setbacks, the makers of the Pebble wristwatch, a device that can wirelessly link to a smartphone and that raised more than $10 million on Kickstarter, say they are finally ready to start shipping to eager customers.

abstract: Nearly six months after signing off ABC’s “Good Morning America” to fight a life-threatening illness, Robin Roberts made her return to the top-rated morning show on Wednesday.

abstract: Mr. Daulerio moved up from the sports site Deadspin to take over Gawker in November of 2011.

abstract: The agreement stipulates that no guild members would be laid off in the first year of the contract, in exchange for pay cuts this year and next.

abstract: Has India’s foreign policy toward Sri Lanka been the most disastrous sustained policy it has ever run?

abstract: Berkshire Hathaway’s performance over the last four years has been disappointing. That’s likely to increase the chances of a cash payout, whether from Mr. Buffett or his successor, the author writes.

headline: Questions About China’s Growth, Censorship and Air Pollution
abstract: The new government may be using the aggressive reporting to demonstrate a commitment to transparency and accountability as well as use this crisis to further the difficult reforms toward a more sustainable development model, the author writes.

abstract: With the Vatican among the dwindling number of states that recognize Taiwan, President Ma Ying-jeou’s attendance at Pope Francis’s inaugural Mass is significant.

abstract: A homegrown talent, the comedian Pete Dominick, will move his radio show to a different channel to explore topics like religion, race and education policy.

abstract: Ninety-three percent of all income growth in the U.S. in 2010 went to the top 1 percent. And just 15,000 households received 37 percent of all of those gains.

abstract: A mixed reaction from Spanish-Language media for Senator Marco Rubio. The origins of computer matchmaking. Streaming services create original content for children.

abstract: Researchers at the computer giant said Thursday that they had developed a fluidic electronic system that mimics the way the brain works.

abstract: Sunday’s audience surpassed even the audience for the third season premiere in January, when about 7.9 million viewers tuned in, a 20-year record for PBS.

abstract: Amazon’s Kindle software keeps track of where you left off in the same e-book on all your tablets and phones, but you can clear the information if it gets out of sync.

abstract: In a Punjab village, family of rape victim who committed suicide blame police.

headline: Wall Street Pay Rises, for Those Who Still Have a Job
abstract: The average cash bonus for people employed in New York City in the financial industry rose by roughly 9 percent, to $121,900, in 2012, the New York State comptroller said.

headline: 7 of 8 Ivy League Schools Report Lower Acceptance Rates
abstract: Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell, Columbia, Brown and Penn were more selective when admitting the freshman class of 2013. If Dartmouth follows suit, all eight Ivy League institutions will have reported lower acceptance rates this year.

headline: In Deal, Bank of America Extends Retreat From Mortgages
abstract: The problems at Bank of America have cut down its mortgage ambitions; it accounts for 4 percent of the nation’s mortgage market, a slide from just over 20 percent in 2009, ceding market dominance to Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Chase.

headline: India Could Retaliate Against Pakistan for Beheading, Army Chief Says
abstract: The Indian military may retaliate at a “time of its choosing” for the recent beheading of an Indian soldier by the Pakistani Army, the chief of the Indian Army said Monday, ahead of a meeting at the border of the two countries.

headline: Maybe There Is Such a Thing as Bad Publicity
abstract: A commercial on ABC would have cost TerraCycle hundreds of thousands of dollars and only given it 30 seconds of exposure. Instead, the company got more than three minutes, twice in one month. But at what cost?

headline: The Right and Wrong Way to Buy Girl Scout Cookies
abstract: Parents aren’t supposed to be selling cookies to you at the office. So what should you say when they try to do it anyway?

headline: Predator Drones Keep an Eye on the Border, Documents Show
abstract: Drones on the border are designed to distinguish between animals and humans and tell when humans are carrying a backpack.

headline: When Corruption Helps the Bottom Line
abstract: A recent study found that the most corrupt countries like Venezuela are actually better for investors than moderately corrupt countries like Morocco or Mexico.

headline: Einhorn Versus Apple
abstract: David Einhorn says he still loves Apple, but the company needs to change. | The Federal Reserve may be increasing its effort to spot bubbles on Wall Street. | The charges in the government’s lawsuit against Standard & Poor’s are reminiscent of what happened at Arthur Andersen. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is preparing for a new life in London.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tech Design Comics and Artificial Intelligence Money
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include Internet technologies spreading into more industries, which Web sites share what information and the latest iPhone bug.

headline: Facebook Unveils a New Search Tool
abstract: Facebook’s new tool, graph search, will allow users to look for photos, people and places that their friends like or check into.

headline: From Tamil Brahmin to Kashmiri Pandit: Weddings Across India
abstract: Photographer Sephi Bergerson has documented a wide variety of marriage ceremonies.

headline: Thursday Reading: Revised Rules for Depression Diagnoses
abstract: Revised rules for depression diagnoses, Apple’s falling stock, tech tools for new parents and other consumer news from the last 24 hours in The Times and on our Web site.

headline: Monday Reading: Why Junk Food Is So Addictive
abstract: Why junk food is so addictive, hostels go upscale, fitness at a price of your choosing and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Seeking Your Questions on Paying for College
abstract: Laura Perna, a researcher in college finance and affordability, answers select reader questions about paying for college.

headline: From Disney, a Video Game Universe on One Platform
abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

headline: In Heinz Takeover, a New Path for Deals
abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

headline: Tell Us: Employer Benefits for Same-Sex Couples
abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

headline: Goldman Overcomes Its Latest Headache
abstract: A case brought by the founders of Dragon Systems was among a spate of legal problems and public relations headaches for Goldman in recent years.

headline: Fund-Raising for Schools, Using Old Class Photos
abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Disappointing Super Bowl Ads, and a Hollywood Outsider Makes His Move
abstract: A critique of the Super Bowl ads finds them wanting; Legendary Entertainment, run by a Hollywood outsider, gets a large piece of the blockbuster movie season; and the FX channel embraces the dark side of storytelling.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: What’s New in TVs
abstract: David Pogue walks the floor of the International Consumer Electronics Show and finds humor in the excess — mostly of it unintended by the companies.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: Industry Shifts With Dell Deal
abstract: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: Parental Leave: What Does Your Employer Offer?
abstract: Bucks readers are asked to help provide a progress report that will highlight paid parental leave policies at their employers.

headline: Image of the Day: Feb. 7
abstract: A snow covered field in Gulmarg, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Robin Roberts Plans February Return to ‘Good Morning America’
abstract: After spending the coming weeks working with her doctors toward a return to the set of “Good Morning America,” Ms. Roberts said she has hopes of rejoining the cast next month.

headline: In Apple Fight, Einhorn Unveils ‘iPrefs’
abstract: Apple has introduced perhaps more innovative consumer products than any other company has over the past decade, including the iPhone. Now, the hedge fund manager David Einhorn wants the company to roll out what he calls iPrefs.

headline: Waiting for the Run on the Banks
abstract: After months and months of something passing for blessed calm in the euro zone, the bailout of Cypriot banks rekindles fears of instability in Italy and Spain.

headline: For Many Digital Music Services, Free Is Not a Choice
abstract: To compete against one another, an increasing number of online streaming services are offering free tiers — a move that gets attention, but has always caused worries that it could undermine the value of music.

headline: Fed Transcripts Reveal Concerns About Private Equity Boom
abstract: As the private equity bubble inflated during the first half of 2007, a period defined by record acquisitions by the world’s largest buyout firms, the Federal Reserve took notice.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Retirement and Food Substitutes
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include the United States’ early history of technology theft, Sergey Brin showing Mark Zuckerberg how his Google glasses work and why Nevada’s legalization of online gambling will do little to help social games..

headline: In Jaipur, a Strong Showing From Pakistan, Despite Calls for Boycott
abstract: Following fatal border clashes in Kashmir, some wanted Pakistani writers banned from the Jaipur Literature Festival.

headline: New Stuff I’ve Learned Since My Facebook Privacy Tool Kit
abstract: More tools to help you decide for yourself how much you want to share on Facebook.

headline: Should a Victim of Hurricane Sandy Risk His House to Revive His Business?
abstract: The owner of a company that rents automobiles for film and television production faces a big decision after the storm.

headline: A Conversation With: Author and Mathematician Manil Suri
abstract: On his latest novel, growing up in Mumbai and his passion for writing.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: Panasonic’s TVs Can Recognize a Face
abstract: Panasonic’s new product introductions at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas touch on what is becoming a common theme — that is, making your TV do the work of finding shows you want to watch. Higher-end Panasonic TVs will use face recognition to determine whose preferences to display.

headline: In Praise of Bangla, My Mother Tongue
abstract: Bangla is not just a language, it’s a testament to Bangladesh’s freedom.

headline: New Novel Takes Readers Downstairs at Longbourn
abstract: Jo Baker’s tale of the servants in “Pride and Prejudice” drew frenetic bidding among publishing houses when it was offered last week.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The Times Co. Plans to Sell The Boston Globe, and Robin Roberts Returns
abstract: The New York Times Company plans to sell its New England Media Group, including The Boston Globe; Robin Roberts makes a triumphant return to “Good Morning America”; and the Oscars broadcast on Sunday will rival the Super Bowl as an advertising venue.

headline: Despite Signs of Progress in the Euro Zone, Fears of Complacency Linger
abstract: Europe’s political leaders have taken important steps to improve spending discipline among euro members, but have yet to address some serious flaws in the structure of the euro zone.

headline: From Hyderabad, a Tale of Two Snack Bars
abstract: Examining the long-term impacts of terrorism, from the recent blasts to the 2007 explosions.

headline: Tax Exclusions for Health Insurance
abstract: Policy decisions that created tax exclusions and implicit subsidies have helped the health sector of the economy grow, an economist writes.

headline: A Place That Makes New York Real Estate Look Cheap
abstract: In Beijing, it costs 22.3 times the typical household income to buy a home. The most comparable number for New York is 6.2.

headline: In Filing, News Corp. Says It Will Provide $2.6 Billion to Its New Publishing Company
abstract: The new company, which will consist of more than 100 newspapers, will have a big cash safety net and no debt when it separates from the entertainment part of News Corporation.

headline: Pandora to Limit Free Listening, Citing Royalty Costs
abstract: In a blog post on Wednesday, Tim Westergren, the founder and public face of Pandora, said that a limit of 40 hours a month on mobile devices would take effect this week for its free service.

headline: Time Warner Considers Spinning Off Some of Its Magazines
abstract: Early discussions involve putting most of its titles — but not Time, Fortune or Sports Illustrated — into a separate company with Meredith magazines.

headline: Barnes & Noble Faces Steep Challenge as Holiday Nook Sales Decline
abstract: The company’s Nook unit suffered a 12.6 percent decline in sales compared with the same period a year earlier, a blow to its hopes of building up its digital division to compete with behemoths like Amazon.com.

headline: Condoleezza Rice Becomes CBS News Contributor
abstract: Ms. Rice is expected to comment regularly on national and international issues, CBS said.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 28
abstract: A deadly fire rips through a nightclub in Brazil; Italy tries a new tactic to catch tax cheats; sex education in Indonesia; how the peace sign evolved, and Djokovic takes the title.

headline: App Smart Extra: For the Garden
abstract: As spring arrives, a host of gardening apps.

headline: In Tighter Loan Rules, Wiggle Room for Banks
abstract: Federal regulators, apparently concerned about doing anything to disrupt a recovering housing market, allowed mortgage lenders big concessions in a new slate of regulations.

headline: Kicking Corzine Out of the ‘Club’ Proved to Be Not So Easy
abstract: The National Futures Association tried to impose a lifetime ban on Jon Corzine from the group. The problem, however: he was not even a member.

headline: Square Enters Another Coffee Chain, Blue Bottle
abstract: Blue Bottle, a coffee chain with tech cred, has adopted Square for accepting payments. Small chains like Blue Bottle could be a key to Square’s success.

headline: Women Strip and Beat Politician Accused of Rape in Northeast India
abstract: Women surround a Congress Party politician, remove his shirt and smack him.

headline: Image of the Day: March 7
abstract: A nomadic community from Rajasthan migrates to Madhya Pradesh with the onset of summer.

headline: On Wall Street, Putting Shareholders Second
abstract: If the financial crisis made anything clear, the author contends, it’s that banks should be forced to defend their business models and corporate governance — regularly.

headline: Unwieldy Proposals From Einhorn and Apple
abstract: Amid a spat over preferred stock, both the hedge fund magnate and the iPad maker would benefit from a streamlined approach, the author contends.

headline: After Just Two Episodes, NBC Cancels ‘Do No Harm’
abstract: The premiere a week ago attracted the fewest viewers ever of any new network drama in a regular season — just 3.1 million.

headline: Disney World Gets New President
abstract: George Kalogridis, who has been running Disneyland in California, will take over the top job at resort that draws an estimated 30 million people a year.

headline: The Worst Possible Way to Cut Spending
abstract: Fundamental differences on government’s role, and a fair amount of posturing, are keeping Congress and the president from finding a better way to address budget deficits than across-the-board cuts, an economist writes.

headline: Doubt Is Cast on Firms Hired to Help Banks
abstract: Federal authorities are scrutinizing the private consultants hired by banks to clean up financial misdeeds like money laundering and foreclosure abuses, taking aim at a conflict-riddled, billion-dollar industry.

headline: Daily Report: Zynga at a Crossroads in Mobile Quest
abstract: As its revenue remains flat, the social-game creator faces a crucial test: Can it successfully put its most popular Web games, starting with Farmville, on mobile devices?

headline: A Woman’s Place Is in the House. . . and in the Senate
abstract: A historic tally of women in the legislative branch could bring changes to both the women’s movement and to Congress.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: F.B.I. to Help Investigate American’s Death in Singapore, Reports Say
abstract: The parents of Todd Shane, an American engineer found dead in Singapore last year, believe he may have been murdered, amid warnings of “Chinese spying.” Now Singaporean investigators have asked the F.B.I. to help investigate.

headline: One Recession Cost Is Lower Social Security Benefits
abstract: Drawing your Social Security benefits as soon as you are eligible can affect your long-term well-being, while deferring them offers a savings rate hard to find anywhere else, an economist writes.

headline: Dutch Arts Groups Shut Down as Funding Vanishes
abstract: The Netherlands used to have a reputation as a paradise for artists, but this month dozens of organizations there have had to shut their doors. How should the country’s arts groups go about rebuilding themselves?

headline: Washington Post Says It Will Seek New Home
abstract: The Washington Post, another newspaper struggling to trim costs, is planning to move out of the District of Columbia headquarters where its staff has worked for nearly four decades.

headline: How a Meredith-Time Warner Joint Venture Would Work
abstract: What Time Warner is discussing with Meredith appears to be less a sale of its non-news publications and more the creation of a new joint venture housing substantially all of their magazines, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

headline: A Conversation With: Ania Loomba, Professor at University of Pennsylvania
abstract: Ms. Loomba was one of the professors who opposed Narendra Modi’s participation in the upcoming Wharton India Economic Forum.

headline: A CBS Deal Bolsters Amazon’s Challenge to Netflix
abstract: Slowly but confidently, Amazon is building a library of television shows and movies to rival that of Netflix, much to the satisfaction of media companies like Time Warner and CBS, whose executives love to see the competition.

headline: The Convergence of George Will and Sherrod Brown
abstract: A growing chorus of voices from across the political spectrum is criticizing the size, impact and policies of the largest banks, an economist writes.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 14
abstract: Cardinals choose the first pope from the Americas; a Khmer Rouge leader dies; the E.U. Parliament rejects a budget; censorship in the United Arab Emirates; and Barcelona banishes all doubt in its victory over Milan.

headline: Roundup: Israel and Canada Provide Lessons on Women in Combat
abstract: A look at how Canada and Israel have dealt with integrating women into combat roles.

headline: India’s Budget Targets Women
abstract: Women’s only bank and new safety fund.

headline: Q.& A.: Fixing Incorrect Photo Dates
abstract: If your photos show up in Picasa with the wrong dates for when they were taken, you can correct the timestamps right in the program.

headline: Morgan Stanley Discloses Payouts to Senior Deal Maker
abstract: Morgan Stanley disclosed the timeline for some of its retirement awards to Paul J. Taubman, the senior deal maker who co-led its securities business.

headline: Beneath the Calm, SAC Works to Contain Fallout From Inquiry
abstract: As federal authorities continue to press an insider trading investigation, SAC Capital Advisors, run by Steven A. Cohen, is working to retain clients and staff members.

headline: Q&A: Dumping the Windows Jump List
abstract: Microsoft’s Jump Lists feature in recent versions of Windows is intended to make life easier, but it can be turned off if you would rather not leave a trail of files you have recently used.

headline: Lawmakers in India Charged With Crimes Could Face Speedier Trials
abstract: Supreme Court asks government to fast-track cases against people in office.

headline: Christina Applegate Leaves ‘Up All Night’
abstract: Ms. Applegate announced Friday she has decided to quit the series on NBC rather than continue in a new format, which will transform the comedy from a single camera filmed show, to one filmed on tape in front of a studio audience.

headline: Still Together, 30 Years and 6 Deployments Later
abstract: An Army general and his wife, an Army colonel, talk about their 30 years of marriage, through two children and six deployments.

headline: Daily Report: Algorithms Get a Human Hand in Steering the Web
abstract: Computer algorithms are capable of trading stocks, arranging dates, winning “Jeopardy” and even choosing bra sizes. But increasingly, behind the curtain, there is a human helper.

headline: Istanbul Museum Stroll: At the Pera
abstract: Many of the artists whose works are being shown at the Pera Museum in Istanbul these days might say they owe a debt of gratitude to the 75-year-old cubist painter Muhanna Durra of Jordan.

headline: For Fed Presidents, Economics Is Local
abstract: Dissenters from the Federal Reserve’s stimulus campaign are often those from the districts where economic growth has been the fastest.

headline: Daily Report: Government Takes Legal Action Over Phone Spam
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday that it had recently filed eight lawsuits in federal courts around the country against companies it accused of ordering or engineering the sending of hundreds of millions of spam text messages to mobile phone users.

headline: A Hedge Fund Dogfight, Live, Mesmerizes Wall Street
abstract: Years of bad blood between the two hedge fund magnates spilled publicly onto CNBC’s airwaves on Friday, as Mr. Icahn derided his younger counterpart as a “crybaby,” and Mr. Ackman declared the veteran investor a “bully.”

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.

headline: Dish’s Potemkin Offer for Clearwire
abstract: Although Charlie Ergen’s takeover bid is unlikely to go very far, it could pressure Sprint to pay more — or strike a deal with Dish.

headline: JPMorgan Board Votes to Release ‘London Whale’ Report
abstract: The board of JPMorgan Chase voted Tuesday to release an internal report detailing the bad bet — and related management missteps — that cost the nation’s largest bank more than $6 billion, according to several people familiar with the matter.

headline: On ABC Family, an Episode in Sign Language
abstract: On Monday night, the channel broadcast an episode of “Switched at Birth” in sign language, with closed captioning turned on by default.

headline: North Korea: Tweeting Its Way to the Future?
abstract: North Korea, one of the most cut-off nations on earth, appears to have an official Twitter account. It contains some surprises.

headline: Austerity
abstract: A bottle of “Austerity”-brand wine.

headline: Herbalife Shares Fall After Company Defends Itself
abstract: The nutritional supplements company sought to knock down William A. Ackman’s accusations that it was a fraud, but it appeared that investors were still trying to make up their minds.

headline: Big Music Companies Are Said to Pursue a Top Dance Promoter
abstract: Live Nation and SFX Entertainment, two companies among the biggest players in live music, are said to be interested in buying Insomniac Events, the biggest promoter of electronic dance music in the country.

headline: School Rankings: What’s in a Number?
abstract: One of the more reputable university ranking systems charges some schools to be assessed. Critics wonder how trustworthy and neutral some college listings are.

headline: Greens Outside — and Inside — the Tent at Davos
abstract: At the World Economic Forum this week, the heads of major environmental organizations are more likely to be found inside the security perimeter than outside.

headline: Brother of a Fallen Hedge Fund King Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Rengan Rajaratnam pleaded not guilty on Monday to insider trading charges, coming nearly two years after the conviction of his older brother, the fallen hedge fund titan Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: Fox Shelves ‘Ben and Kate’ on Tuesdays
abstract: The show, about a brother and sister living together with her young daughter, has posted weak ratings all season.

headline: The Best Asian Art? You Can Vote on It
abstract: What is Asian art, exactly? That depends on how you define Asia, as a contest based in Hong Kong demonstrates.

headline: Solar Cells May Supplement Smartphone Batteries
abstract: Solar cells under development by a Silicon Valley start-up, Alta Devices, could give smartphone batteries a boost of as much as 80 percent of a battery’s power. The company uses hybrid gallium arsenide solar cells, which are better at capturing energy than silicon solar cells.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: How Rodman Wound Up in North Korea, and AMC Lurches Ahead in Ratings
abstract: Vice magazine was behind Dennis Rodman’s high-profile trip to North Korea; “The Walking Dead” is killing networks in the ratings; and a photojournalists in Oakland, Calif., have become victims of a rash of robberies.

headline: Wanelo: Social Commerce Site Is Big With Young Shoppers
abstract: Wanelo, an up-and-coming e-commerce site, lets people browse through beautifully arranged collections of clothing and other items, and links visitors to stores where they can buy the products.

headline: The Small Picture: Meet Pumbaa, One Lucky Pig
abstract: Pumbaa lives at Whynot Farm on Snow Creek, where the owner calls him “a sweet hog whom we cannot bring ourselves to slaughter.”

abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.
