abstract: It has become much more common for Americans over 65 to continue working, if they can.

headline: Daily Report: Health Data Swells Profits in an Industry
abstract: As doctors and hospitals struggle to make new records systems work, the winners are big companies that lobbied for the legislation that allowed their sales to soar, Julie Creswell reports.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Regulating Mexico’s Telecom Industry and Fox’s Push for College Sports
abstract: Mexican politicians introduced legislation to regulate telecom giants, Fox Sports 1 has accumulated the broadcast rights for many college conferences and Lisa Pulitzer has cornered the literary marketplace for memoirs of escaped cultists.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 23
abstract: Cyprus partly approves a formula to obtain a bailout; Israel apologizes to Turkey; the writer Chinua Achebe dies; cargo ships in trouble; and the Malaysian Grand Prix.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 9
abstract: Peace without optimism in Afghanistan’s south; euro-zone unemployment hits a new high; Obama’s increasingly male inner circle; a slapdash post-Fukushima cleanup.

headline: Marketing Tips for Reaching Hispanic Americans
abstract: A marketing expert says call centers report that the average handling time for Hispanic callers is significantly greater than for non-Hispanics. Does it matter?

headline: This Week in Small Business: Leave the Building
abstract: G.D.P. slips. Optimism rises. And the intrigue continues at Downton Arby’s. Will immigration reform help your business?

headline: An Expensive but Logical Cable Deal
abstract: The revelation that Vodafone of Britain is looking at Germany’s biggest cable operator has understandably unnerved its shareholders, the author writes.

headline: The Political Realignment on Full Display
abstract: The vote on the legislation to avert the fiscal cliff revealed how the parties and the country have changed — and how fraught the crucial votes over the coming months will be.

headline: Image of the Day: March 28
abstract: A demonstration seeking better educational and employment opportunities for the disabled in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Compuware Rejects Elliott’s $2.3 Billion Bid
abstract: The business software maker said that it was focused on its own corporate turnaround blueprint, including cost cuts and a spinoff of a communications products arm.

headline: News Corp. to Unveil Education Product With Its Own Tablet
abstract: The tablet, a 10-inch Android device for kindergartners through 12th graders, will come with the company’s education curriculum, which can also be used on other devices.

headline: Tinder, a Dating App With a Difference
abstract: A new mobile dating application called Tinder appears to be taking off among college students for its simple and flirty interface. Its founders say the application is downloaded more than 20,000 times each day.

headline: Daily Report: A Billion-Dollar Club, and Not So Exclusive
abstract: An unprecedented number of high technology start-ups, including Evernote and Spotify, are valued at $1 billion or more and remain privately held. With the size comes bigger expectations.

headline: One Phone Call From Disaster
abstract: If you have business partners, a buy/sell agreement isn’t just important — it’s crucial.

headline: French Screen Diva Threatens Russia Exile, Too
abstract: First Gérard Depardieu. Now Brigitte Bardot. France’s most famous movie icon is threatening to flee to Russia. But this time it’s not about taxes — it’s about elephants.

headline: Gibraltar Seeks to Woo Brazilian Hedge Funds and Private Equity
abstract: Government officials from the British territory of Gibraltar visited Rio de Janeiro this week to promote its financial stability as well as its access to the European Union and low taxes.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Loss at DreamWorks Animation, and a Cute Interspecies Rescue Was Fake
abstract: DreamWorks suffered an earnings loss and talked about staff cuts; a heartwarming YouTube video of a pig rescuing a goat that was fodder for many news outlets was faked; and “American Idol” tries to close the feedback loop on TV hashtags.

headline: Preschool Economics
abstract: It makes good economic sense, as well as good public policy, to expand early-childhood education and defend early-childhood programs against budget-cutters, an economist writes.

headline: Number of Tibetans Self-Immolating Nears 100
abstract: A report lists the names, ages, parents and aspirations of 98 Tibetans who killed themselves since February 2009.

headline: What the Cyprus Bailout Could Mean for Europe’s Debt
abstract: Some economists say that they are optimistic about reducing Europe’s debt levels after leaders took controversial steps in the Cyprus bailout.

headline: Doctors Say Barbara Walters Has Chicken Pox
abstract: Ms. Walters, who is 83, fell after suffering a fainting spell in Washington last week, and a lingering fever has kept her hospitalized.

headline: Q&A: Reformatting a Kindle Fire
abstract: Before you give away or sell your old Kindle Fire, you can erase all your personal content and settings on the tablet in just a few steps.

headline: A Simpler Way to Complain About Student Loan Collections
abstract: The Department of Education has improved its online system for complaints about federal student loan collections.

headline: The Temptation to Trade on Confidential Information
abstract: Two recent insider trading cases seem to indicate that the desire for quick profits is simply clouding our judgment, the author writes.

headline: Will Yahoo Increase Productivity by Banning People From Working at Home?
abstract: A new policy at Yahoo requiring that people work in the office strikes some people as behind the curve, though the company says it will improve collaboration and momentum.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 13
abstract: Syria’s military under strain; a shortage of tourism workers in Australia; the pope watch continues; France proposes new rules for internet equal access; Japan extracts gas from “flammable ice”; and the right to remain silent in soccer.

headline: Starz Extends Deal With Sony Pictures
abstract: The pay cable channel has completed a deal with Sony Pictures Entertainment, extending an agreement for exclusive access to Sony movies through 2021.

headline: Fox News and Dick Morris Part Ways
abstract: The Fox News Channel has declined to renew its contract with Mr. Morris, three months after he was widely derided for predicting a landslide victory for Mitt Romney in the Nov. 6 presidential election.

headline: Five Questions for: Author Uday Prakash
abstract: Mr. Prakash is one of the few Hindi writers to be published by an American publisher.

headline: Krolls’ K2 Firm Buys a Corporate Watchdog
abstract: K2 Intelligence, the investigative business started by Jules Kroll and Jeremy Kroll, has acquired Thacher Associates, a leading player in the niche business of overseeing large-scale real estate development projects on behalf of governments and developers to ferret out corruption in the construction process.

headline: A Conversation With: Sotheby’s Lord Poltimore
abstract: On Sotheby’s expansion plans in India and the growing art market.

headline: Memories of Floating Over Luxor, Now Tinged With the Macabre
abstract: A family hardly thought about danger when they booked a balloon ride, a staple of Luxor vacations. Less than two months later, a crash on one of those very balloons killed at least 18.

headline: Wells Fargo Kicks Off Bank Earnings
abstract: Wells Fargo announces earnings Thursday morning, amid signs that the housing market may be beginning a recovery. | The settlement this week with 10 big banks ends a foreclosure review process that was deeply flawed. | The models regulators use to assess risk may be useful during normal times, but not when they matter the most, a federal agency said. | Herbalife sought on Thursday to counter accusations that the company was a fraud, but investors were still making up their minds.

headline: Private Equity Players See Signs of Excess in Buyout Market
abstract: Speaking at the annual SuperReturn conference in Berlin, several private equity executives discussed concerns about the recent flurry of deal-making activity.

headline: How Children Learn to Sell
abstract: Bucks readers share their own stories of how they and their children learned to make a sales pitch and close a deal, all before they turned 18.

headline: Glimpses of Jean Arp’s World
abstract: While his peers were working in Montmartre, Jean Arp headed to the suburbs, where visitors who make the brief trek from Paris can see where he lived and worked.

headline: Momentum Seems to Build for Gargantuan Buyout of Dell
abstract: Dell appears to be hoping that going private can help ease its woes. But the hurdles to both completing a big leveraged buyout and to solving its ongoing business problems aren’t going away anytime soon.

headline: Two Precedents Republicans Can Look to
abstract: William F. Buckley and William Jefferson Clinton both moved to counter extreme elements in their movements — successfully.

headline: Visa Teams Up With Samsung on Mobile Payments
abstract: The idea of paying for things with a phone is still foreign to most people, but now Visa and Samsung Electronics are working together to make mobile payments easier.

headline: From Disney, a Video Game Universe on One Platform
abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

headline: In Heinz Takeover, a New Path for Deals
abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

headline: Tell Us: Employer Benefits for Same-Sex Couples
abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

headline: Goldman Overcomes Its Latest Headache
abstract: A case brought by the founders of Dragon Systems was among a spate of legal problems and public relations headaches for Goldman in recent years.

headline: Fund-Raising for Schools, Using Old Class Photos
abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Disappointing Super Bowl Ads, and a Hollywood Outsider Makes His Move
abstract: A critique of the Super Bowl ads finds them wanting; Legendary Entertainment, run by a Hollywood outsider, gets a large piece of the blockbuster movie season; and the FX channel embraces the dark side of storytelling.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: What’s New in TVs
abstract: David Pogue walks the floor of the International Consumer Electronics Show and finds humor in the excess — mostly of it unintended by the companies.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: Industry Shifts With Dell Deal
abstract: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: Bloomberg Doubles Its Tech Television
abstract: Bloomberg Television is adding a morning technology program to its lineup. Executives there say it reflects a growing interest in the topic.

headline: India’s Capital City Celebrates ‘Design Week’
abstract: The best of Indian design, showcased in New Delhi.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 23
abstract: Bank’s downfall in Italy; European growth stumbles; more horse meat fallout, and David Lynch branches out.

headline: Maybe You Don’t Really Need Investors
abstract: This owner was falling for the myth that comes from Silicon Valley and shows like “Shark Tank” — that you need investors to make great things happen.

headline: Barclays Sets Aside $1.6 Billion More for Legal Costs
abstract: The British bank Barclays has made additional provisions totaling $1.6 billion to cover legal costs related to the inappropriate selling of insurance and interest-rate hedging products.

headline: Documents in S.& P. Case Show Alarm
abstract: Documents in a lawsuit against Standard & Poor’s provide a glimpse at the company’s inner working in the run-up to the financial crisis. | Royal Bank of Scotland poised to settle accusations that it manipulated Libor. | Debevoise & Plimpton is eliminating its trusts and estates practice. | The fate of Hostess Brands shows how corporate machinations can both doom and save a company.

headline: In Davos, Atmosphere for Bankers Improves
abstract: Among the government overseers who will be in attendance at the World Economic Forum, there appears to be a growing sentiment that banks have taken enough abuse.

headline: Global Slavery, by the Numbers
abstract: A Big Data start-up analyzed reports from governments and human rights organizations, then presented its findings in a pretty graphic full of ugly truths. Among the findings: Slaves may cost as little as $60, and children are often used for fishing and harvesting stones.

headline: Green Groups Decry Sequester’s Effects
abstract: From environmental programs to renewable energy support to all kinds of inspections, the more than $80 billion in automatic budget cuts will have an impact.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 4
abstract: Doctors say a baby with H.I.V. has been cured; a man suspected of wildlife smuggling operations seems beyond reach in Laos; an escalating battle between union workers and Amazon in Germany; more Indian students are taking the International Baccalaureate; and the Premier League continues to flaunt its international soccer talent.

headline: Reporter’s Notebook: Snapchat’s Path From Stanford to the Beach
abstract: How Snapchat went from a project of two roommates to a photo app sensation, with headquarters in a beach house on the Venice boardwalk in Los Angeles.

headline: Carville and Matalin Part Ways With CNN
abstract: The husband-and-wife, Democrat-and-Republican pair are two of CNN’s best-known contributors. For years they co-hosted “Crossfire”; after it was canceled, they were regulars on “The Situation Room” and election night specials.

headline: Schultz to Give Up Weekday Slot on MSNBC
abstract: Ed Schultz, host of “The Ed Show,” will take a new weekend shift in April.

headline: When You Hire the Right Person for the Wrong Position
abstract: What do you do if it turns out that the job itself is not a good fit for the company?

headline: European Regulators Fine Microsoft, and Then Promise to Do Better
abstract: The European Union fined Microsoft $732 million on Wednesday for failing to respect an antitrust settlement with regulators, but in a highly unusual admission, the union’s top antitrust regulator said his department bore some responsibility for situation that led to the fine.

headline: Big Hikes in Rural, Social Spending in India’s New Budget
abstract: Farm loans, rural health programs, education among the areas where spending will increase.

headline: The Promise and Peril of the ‘Data-Driven Society’
abstract: The prospect of a “data-driven society” was the subject of a gathering last Thursday at the M.I.T. Media Lab — the implications, the concerns and the unknowns. For example, the most important data that is becoming available on a vast new scale is information about people’s behavior: the social and economic connections among individuals.

headline: Profit Slides 6% at Disney as Movie and TV Divisions Lag
abstract: Increases in costs for programming like basketball and football at ESPN provided a drag on the results from Disney’s media networks unit. Walt Disney Studios struggled compared with the same period a year earlier.

headline: ‘This American Life’ Looks at a High School Marooned in Violence
abstract: At Chicago’s Harper High School, 29 current or former students were shot last year. “This American Life” spent five months at the school, and begins a two-part special report this weekend.

headline: … as the Netherlands Salutes Its Departing Monarch
abstract: The Netherlands is losing a queen, but gaining its first king in more than a century.

headline: Streaming Lifts Home Entertainment Spending
abstract: Total spending on film and television in home entertainment formats rose slightly in 2012 to about $18 billion, according to the Digital Entertainment Group, a trade association.

headline: Guilty Plea and Big Fine for Bank in Rate Case
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland on Wednesday reached a combined $612 million settlement with American and British authorities over accusations that it manipulated interest rates, the latest case to emerge from a broad international investigation.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 16
abstract: Meteor damage in Russia; corruption in Spain; challenge in Afghanistan; Scottish whiskey fight.

headline: CVC Capital to Buy Cerved for $1.49 Billion
abstract: CVC Capital Partners has agreed to buy the Italian credit data and business intelligence company Cerved from two rival private equity firms, Bain Capital and Clessidra.

headline: Returns at Hedge Funds Run by Women Beat the Industry, Report Says
abstract: Hedge funds led by female managers produced a return of 8.95 percent through the third quarter of 2012, significantly outperforming the overall universe of hedge funds, a report to be released Thursday by the firm Rothstein Kass shows.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Bush Hacking, and Online Gambling From New Jersey
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include Bluefin Labs’ genesis in a study of how a baby learned language, an indicator of the profitability of smartphone makers and a Web site that allows online tracking of plows in New York City during the big snowstorm.

headline: ‘Running with the Big Boys’ in Iraq, a Female Soldier Paves the Way
abstract: “If or when a female soldier someday enlists in the Army infantry, she will probably look a lot like Sgt. Amber Sellers, 29, from Cullman, Alabama,” writes Nathan S. Webster, an Army veteran.

headline: Apple Computers Hit by Sophisticated Cyberattack
abstract: Apple says its systems were attacked by the same group that hit Twitter and Facebook. Like Facebook, Apple confirmed that its employees’ computers were infected with malware when they visited a Web site for mobile developers.

headline: Thinking of Planting Some Grapes? Get in Line
abstract: European vignerons mounted a furious campaign against loosening up planting regulations. If growers could plant vines willy-nilly, the image of proud place names like Gevrey-Chambertin, Margaux or Barolo would be undermined. But does the rule stymie the European wine industry’s chance to compete, or enhance it?

headline: Buyout Effort Ended, Best Buy Founder Returns to Company
abstract: Richard Schulze, who explored and then abandoned a possible buyout bid for Best Buy, is returning to the electronics chain he founded as chairman emeritus.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Revises $20.1 Billion Takeover Plan
abstract: Anheuser-Busch InBev has revised its $20.1 billion deal for Grupo Modelo, the Mexican maker of Corona beer, as it seeks to persuade American antitrust authorities to let the deal proceed.

headline: New Bilingual Web Site to Focus on Latino Health
abstract: This site, called Vida Vibrante, will focus on health and wellness issues affecting Latinos.

headline: Image of the Day: March 12
abstract: Tibetan exiles in Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh, commemorate Tibetan Women’s Uprising Day.

headline: In Swartz Tribute, Hackers Attack M.I.T. Site
abstract: Anonymous, the loose collective of hackers, attacked the Web site of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Sunday, in a tribute to Aaron Swartz, the 26-year-old technology programmer who died on Friday.

headline: Taming the Runaway U.S. Budget
abstract: To assure markets and reign in what will be a disastrous deficit over the long-term, action needs to be taken soon. But cuts do not have to take place immediately.

headline: Monday Reading: Preparing a Vegan Passover
abstract: Preparing a vegan Passover, a fight for benefits from long-term care insurance, the causes of hearing loss and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 26
abstract: Cypriots lose trust in banks; no residency for Hong Kong’s foreign domestic helpers; China’s president visits Africa; a Dior exhibit in London; and Japan’s path to the World Cup.

headline: An Emotional Investment in Saving for College
abstract: Choosing how to save for college is an emotional as well as financial decision.

headline: I.S.S. Weighs In Against MetroPCS’s Planned Merger With T-Mobile
abstract: Institutional Shareholder Services largely agreed with major shareholders who have objected to both the debt that the merger would place on the combined company and the stake that MetroPCS shareholders would own of the new entity.

headline: Cargo Ship Losses Weigh on European Banks
abstract: Too many ships and not enough cargo have sent ship values plummeting. Many are not worth what European banks lent to build them.

headline: From Disney, a Video Game Universe on One Platform
abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

abstract: A case brought by the founders of Dragon Systems was among a spate of legal problems and public relations headaches for Goldman in recent years.

abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.

abstract: A critique of the Super Bowl ads finds them wanting; Legendary Entertainment, run by a Hollywood outsider, gets a large piece of the blockbuster movie season; and the FX channel embraces the dark side of storytelling.

abstract: David Pogue walks the floor of the International Consumer Electronics Show and finds humor in the excess — mostly of it unintended by the companies.

abstract: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: Why Pixel Counts Don’t Count in Cameras
abstract: Camera manufacturers are bringing out new models but falling back on old marketing strategy. Here is why pixel counts shouldn’t count when buying a camera.

headline: Measuring the Success of Online Education
abstract: Massive open online courses, or MOOCs, tend to have low completion rates, some with 10 percent or fewer students actually finishing. But because they are computerized, the courses offer an ideal medium for quantifying what works and what doesn’t, and researchers are paying attention.

headline: Preoccupying My Mind With Summer Plans as Colleges Decide My Fate
abstract: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student in New Delhi who is applying to universities in the United States, is avoiding the anxiety of college decisions by making plans for summer.

headline: At Davos: Goldman’s Chief Bears a New Look
abstract: Chief executives often treat the World Economic Forum in Davos as a chance to air fresh ideas about business and economics. But for Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, it was an opportunity to unveil a beard.

headline: Disruptions: Smart Guns Can’t Kill in the Wrong Hands
abstract: Technology exists that would make guns safer. But the possibility of preventing or at least limiting deaths this way is missing from the gun-control debate.

headline: Comparing the Quality of Care in Medicare Options
abstract: While anecdotal evidence delivers a mixed verdict, the likelihood is that Medicare Advantage plans outperform traditional Medicare, an economist writes.

headline: Thursday Reading: How to Buy and Install a Generator
abstract: How to buy and install an electric generator, living the bed-and-breakfast dream, a slimmer keyboard for the iPad and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Rajat Gupta Seeks Reversal of Insider Trading Conviction
abstract: Lawyers for Rajat Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs director, have made several arguments on appeal. Among the most significant is that the government should not have been allowed to use certain wiretap evidence during his trial.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Awkwardness at NBC, and Barbara Walters’ Retirement
abstract: NBC has yet to learn how to handle successions gracefully, Barbara Walters will retire in 2014, and Christopher Cuomo and Kate Bolduan will host a new CNN morning show.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Groupon Goes Gunless, and Siri’s Roots
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include Esty making an acquisition, a commentary on an interview with a former Microsoft employee about his book on the company’s chief, and misconfigured home security cameras.

headline: Netflix Teams With DreamWorks Animation on Cartoon Series for Children
abstract: The two companies will combine on a show based on the studio’s upcoming movie “Turbo.”

headline: British Panel Castigates Ex-UBS Officials at Hearing
abstract: A parliamentary panel denounced the former UBS bankers for expressing ignorance of the Libor manipulation during the financial crisis.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Favorite Stories
abstract: American Experience, the PBS history series, has told the history of the Silicon Valley from the beginning. It is a lively but idealized portrait.

headline: A Cheat Sheet for Airline Fees
abstract: The Web site Airfarewatchdog offers a chart listing fees on 14 major airlines.

headline: Brahmaputra Dams Promise Prosperity But at a Big Cost
abstract: In the Brahmaputra River system, planners face a Hobson’s choice between the twin goals of climate change adaptation and mitigation.

headline: ‘This City Is Cursed’
abstract: Residents of Hyderabad speak out after recent explosions.

headline: More Options to Dock Your iPhone 5 From Philips
abstract: Tthe Dutch electronics maker Philips has introduced an array of docking speakers with Apple Lightning connectors for the iPhone 5.

headline: Golden Globes Ratings Surge
abstract: Sunday’s broadcast on NBC, hosted by Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, drew the best ratings for the show in six years, jumping to 19.7 million from 16.8 million viewers in 2012.

headline: In Dell, Shifting Attitude Toward Buyouts
abstract: The battle over Dell suggests that investors today may be slightly less short-term greedy than previous generations. | A collection of internal e-mails at the law firm DLA Piper could reinforce a perception that law firms inflate bills. | Puerto Rico is fashioning a new identity for itself as a tax haven. | A report says that the board of Hulu has approached potential buyers.

headline: India’s Airports Told to Not Let Italian Ambassador Fly
abstract: Latest in an escalating diplomatic row over shooting of two Indian fishermen.

headline: A Highly Public Trip for China’s President, and Its First Lady
abstract: China’s leadership has been promoting a concept called the “Chinese Dream” that depends on continued economic growth and stable relations with the United States. Apple, meanwhile, finds itself the target of attacks in the official media.

headline: The Last Man Asian Literary Prize
abstract: The literary prize carries a $30,000 purse and gives global exposure to Asian authors writing in Asian languages. But as the prize grew in prominence, so have its recipients, causing more crossover with international awards. Does Asia’s literary scene still need Western financing, publishing houses and publicity to succeed?

headline: Bala Panditji, a Priest from Delhi
abstract: Religion means “understanding oneself,” one Kumbh Mela participant says.

headline: Should a Cash-Poor Entrepreneur Give Up Control to Keep Her Start-Up Alive?
abstract: For Jacqui Rosshandler, the decision came down to this question: Isn’t 25 percent of something better than 100 percent of nothing?

headline: The Icahn Effect on Herbalife Shares
abstract: Shares of Herbalife surged after the disclosure that Carl C. Icahn had taken a big stake. But that enthusiasm appeared to fade a bit once Mr. Icahn appeared on CNBC to explain his reasons for investing in the nutritional supplements company.

headline: Relational Urges Hess to Talk With Elliott
abstract: Relational Investors wrote in a letter to Hess’s board on Tuesday that, like Elliott Management, it has found the company’s response lacking.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 12
abstract: New source for Africa’s arms trade; France intervenes in Mali fighting; abuse by British television host detailed; examinations of new Boeing jets planned.

headline: Edelman Names Executive for New Content Role
abstract: Steve Rubel, who had been executive vice president for global strategy and insights at Edelman in New York, is being named the agency’s chief content strategist.

headline: Still Seeking College Application Essays About Money
abstract: A clip from the Marketplace Money public radio program about the Your Money team’s continuing search for what college applicants are writing about money.

headline: Friday Reading: Some Travelers Can Keep Their Shoes On
abstract: The Transportation Security Administration is letting some travelers keep their shoes on, why you shrink as you age, more guns were confiscated at airports last year and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: The Limits of China’s Market Model
abstract: An interview with James McGregor, whose book “No Ancient Wisdom, No Followers” argues that the long-term prospects for China’s economy are being hurt by state dominance and protectionism.

headline: Hulu Names an Acting Chief Executive
abstract: The online video Web site Hulu, in a state of flux as its owners decide what to do with it, said that Andy Forssell, the person in charge of content for the site, would become its acting chief executive.

headline: Four Tips for Better Sunrise Photos
abstract: Rick Sammon, a professional photographer, explains how to get better sunrise and sunset photos.

headline: Putin Grants a Passport to Depardieu
abstract: In the latest development in Gerard Depardieu’s feud with France’s Socialist government, Russia’s President Putin has granted the actor citizenship.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Video Campaign Pushes Paper, and Denmark’s Unexpected Advocates of Free Speech
abstract: A huge paper company promotes paper’s usefulness in a digital age; Denmark’s Muslim groups champion free speech, even when they consider that speech odious; and music supervisors are snubbed by the Oscars.

headline: The Hard Math on Fossil Fuels
abstract: Even the recent reduction in carbon-dioxide emissions in the United States is not nearly sharp enough to avoid reaching what climate scientists consider the prudent limit in global warming within decades.

headline: Blackout Is a Boon for Super Bowl Ratings
abstract: The interruption was not only a diversion, but also changed the momentum in the game, helping to retain an audience that otherwise might have tuned out.

headline: Reverberations After the Bolshoi Attack
abstract: While the investigation of the attack on the director of the Bolshoi continues, the news media has focused on the long history of internecine war at the ballet company.

headline: Rolling Stone Lays Off Two Noted Staff Members
abstract: Eric Bates, the magazine’s executive editor who had worked there for nearly a decade, was laid off on Jan. 4. Mark Neschis, who handled press for Wenner Media, which owns Rolling Stone, reported for his last day on Jan. 11.

headline: Deal Between Office Depot and OfficeMax Not Quite Ready for Release
abstract: The botched announcement is only one reason the deal looks half-baked. The companies also didn’t clearly address the issues of governance and antitrust.

abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: In Maharashtra, Fight Over Restaurant Bill Erupts into Riot
abstract: Five killed from police fire and over 200 injured during riots in Dhule city, Maharashtra.

headline: Hong Kong Holiday Makeover, in Lights
abstract: Hong Kong goes into overdrive for the holiday season, as Christmas lights morph into Chinese New Year lights.

headline: Daily Report: Barnes & Noble Weighs Its E-Reader Investment
abstract: In Monday’s New York Times, Leslie Kaufman reports on the outlook for Barnes & Noble’s Nook Media division, which includes sales of e-books and devices. Losses in the division are considerable, and might signal that the digital approach taken by Barnes & Noble has essentially run its course.

headline: Will Turkey Make Peace With the Kurds?
abstract: In the latest step towards ending Turkey’s long-running conflict with Kurdish rebels, a reported peace plan includes a formal end to hostilities next month.

headline: Image of the Day: Jan. 30
abstract: India commemorates the 65th anniversary of the death of M. K. Gandhi.

headline: Addressing Fears About LED Light Bulbs
abstract: A column about LED light bulbs generated a lot of reader e-mail, probably because LED represents change. And change is always scary. David Pogue addresses some reader concerns.

headline: Judge Sides With Einhorn and Halts an Apple Shareholder Vote
abstract: A federal judge on Friday ordered Apple to halt collecting shareholder votes on a contentious proposal to change some of its corporate charter, handing a victory to the hedge fund manager David Einhorn.

headline: When Good Drivers Pay More for Insurance Than Bad Ones
abstract: A Consumer Federation of America analysis found that lower-income drivers with clean accident records often pay higher auto insurance premiums than higher-income drivers who have caused an accident.

headline: Chief of the Jefferies Group Earned $19 Million in 2012
abstract: Richard B. Handler, the chief executive of Jefferies, made more in 2012 than Jamie Dimon, head of JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Raids in Russia Target ‘Foreign Agents’
abstract: Russia has dismissed Western concerns about a wave of raids targeting civil society groups in Russia. Could President Vladimir V. Putin’s latest hard-line tactic to marginalize his opponents backfire on the Kremlin leader?

headline: The Truthers of Pakistan
abstract: Conspiracy theories persist in Pakistan because they often turn out to be true, author argues.

headline: TimesCast: Creating the Nation’s Largest Airline
abstract: Ending a yearlong courtship by US Airways, American Airlines agreed to merge with the smaller carrier, paving the way for the creation of the nation’s largest airline.

headline: Bina Kumari, the Farmworker from Bihar
abstract: The 32-year-old woman was separated from her family of 11 during the Kumbh Mela.

headline: InterMedia Forms Media Group Focusing on Puerto Rican Viewers
abstract: InterMedia Partners, the private equity firm that owns the Puerto Rican broadcast network WAPA Television and the cable channels WAPA America and Cine Latino, announced on Wednesday that it would merge its Spanish language properties to form a new Hispanic media company called the Hemisphere Media Group.

headline: What India’s New ‘Anti-Rape’ Bill Actually Says
abstract: A breakdown of new charges, punishments and rules for handling sexual assault cases.

headline: A Big Picture From a Small Projector
abstract: The pocket-size iPower Sight can take what is on a phone, tablet or computer screen and project it up to 200 inches diagonally.

headline: Icahn Is Said to Have a Growing Stake in Dell, and No Taste for Buyout
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the veteran activist investor, is poised to announce his opposition to Dell’s proposed $24.4 billion sale to its founder, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Britain Fines UBS Over Sales of a Money Market Fund
abstract: The Financial Services Authority, Britain’s main financial regulator, fined UBS £9.45 million on Tuesday for improperly selling an A.I.G. fund.

headline: Joining the Toad Patrols of Britain
abstract: Toads are creatures of habit, heading back to their home bodies of water each spring to spawn. In Britain, that often means crossing busy roads. Groups of volunteers have sprung up to help them safely find their way home.

headline: Q&A: Creating Customized Shortcuts for Microsoft Word
abstract: Microsoft Word comes with plenty of built-in keyboard shortcuts for common menu commands, but you can also make your own shortcuts.

headline: Valuing Chrysler Too Cheaply
abstract: Fiat needs to raise its offer to buy a slice of the Detroit manufacturer from the United Automobile Workers’ retiree health care trust, the author contends.

headline: Private Equity in China: Which Way Out?
abstract: Of the 10,000 deals that were done during China’s private equity boom of the past decade, about 7,500 are still searching for an exit.

headline: New Research Shows Smaller Gap Between Warming and Carbon Dioxide at Ice Age’s End
abstract: A meticulous new analysis of Antarctic ice suggests that the sharp warming that ended the last ice age occurred in lock step with increases of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, the latest of many indications that the gas is a powerful influence on the earth’s climate.

headline: Employers Also Chase Mutual Fund Performance
abstract: Employers, not just employees, tend to chase investment returns and pick funds for retirement plans based on what has done well recently, a new analysis finds.

headline: Court Opens Delhi Gang Rape Trial to Press
abstract: The Delhi High Court ruled on Friday that reporters can now start attending the trial of the Dec. 16 fatal gang rape case that has sparked widespread outrage in India.

headline: Indian ‘Who Wants to Be a Millionaire’ Winner Trains Others to Win
abstract: What’s next after winning ‘Kaun Banega Crorepati?’ Opening a coaching institute for game show contestants, naturally.

headline: SAC Capital Manager Awaits Word on Charges
abstract: Federal authorities are deciding whether to charge Michael Steinberg, a longtime portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, in an investigation of insider trading at the firm.

headline: Introducing Fashioning Change: Wear This, Not That

headline: With New Chinese Leaders in Place, Waiting for an Agenda to Emerge

abstract: Consumers and merchants share war stories from their own attempts to dispute debit or credit card purchases or defend against these complaints.

abstract: Lost sleep can lead to weight gain, a new approach to hip surgery, hotel guests check in without a front desk and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: The 2012 Patent Rankings: IBM on Top (Again), Google and Apple Surging
abstract: The yearly count of corporate patent winners shows I.B.M. on top in 2012, for the 20th consecutive year. But the big movement in the rankings comes from two combatants in the smartphone patent wars, Google and Apple. Both companies had surge of patents granted last year.

abstract: The Weather Channel has bestowed storms with names like Athena, Caesar, Freyr, Iago, and Kahn. This one brings to mind the adorable orange fish in the Disney/Pixar film, “Finding Nemo.”

headline: Video: For Investors, Apple Not as Shiny
abstract: The Times’s Nick Wingfield talks about Apple’s detrimental legacy of success.

headline: In Delhi Gang Rape Case, a Controversial, Outspoken Lawyer for the Defense

headline: Turkey Hints at a Breakup With Europe
abstract: Turkey’s prime minister denounced the European Union’s alleged stalling on his country’s longstanding membership bid. But is he bluffing when he says Turkey will look east?

headline: A Costly Desalination Plant in California Might Become a Bargain
abstract: A $1 billion seawater desalination plant that is being built in California’s San Diego County is a long-term gamble that the price for water will keep going up.

headline: Judges’ Spat Strikes a Chord Among Deal Makers
abstract: Delaware judges have used the bully pulpit to right wrongs and guide the behavior of lawyers and their clients. Going too far, however,can create confusion.

abstract: The film school at Chapman University in California is experimenting with moviemaking for a profit, with films directed by Chapman alumni.

headline: Predicting Commutes More Accurately for Would-Be Home Buyers
abstract: On its Web site, Windermere, a real estate firm, has begun using an online tool from Inrix, a company that does crowdsourced traffic estimates. It gives those looking for a home an hour-by-hour prediction of the drive times to their workplaces.

abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: In a Compact Container, a Terabyte of Storage
abstract: Kingston Digital introduced a flash drive slightly larger than a Bic lighter that can store a terabyte of data.

headline: Sustainable Living in Your Headphones
abstract: The new collection of headphones from the House of Marley incorporates materials like canvas and bamboo fiber over a frame of aluminum and steel so you can feel better about yourself while listening to music.

headline: The State of Small-Business Lending
abstract: As a loan broker, I speak every day to business owners who are trying to borrow money and bankers who say they want to lend it. Here is what I see happening on the front lines.

headline: New Phone by Facebook to Showcase Its Network
abstract: Facebook will introduce a version of Google’s Android software system next week that is modified to put the social network front and center on a smartphone. The software will make its debut on a handset made by HTC, said a Facebook employee who had been briefed on the product.

headline: S.E.C. Ends Scrutiny of Former Top Aide to Buffett
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided not to file insider trading charges against David L. Sokol, a onetime top lieutenant at Berkshire Hathaway and aide to Warren E. Buffett, according to Mr. Sokol’s lawyer, Barry Wm. Levine.

headline: Disruptions: Data Without Context Tells a Misleading Story
abstract: According to Google Flu Trends, at the flu season’s peak in mid-January, nearly 11 percent of the United States population had influenza — double the official federal estimates.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: What Steve Jobs and Palm Said, and Explorer Nostalgia
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Wednesday, selections include discussions between Apple and Palm about not hiring each other’s employees, some initial results from Facebook’s new search tool, a new smartphone with two screens and a Microsoft ad for Explorer that focuses on nostalgia.

headline: A Deposit by Credit Card That’s Returned by Paper Check
abstract: Cox Communications will only refund deposits on paper checks.

headline: Parental Leave Policies at Some Big Technology Firms
abstract: Facebook’s benefits for new parents include $4,000 in “baby cash” per child.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Quitting Smartphones, and 1950s Computer Art

For Thursday, selections include a video clip of Ashton Kutcher as Steve Jobs in a new movie, a technology group’s effort to take an activist role in New York City elections and Google’s plan to build a private bridge connecting two of its installations.

headline: Goldman Names a New Co-Head of M.&A.
abstract: Goldman Sachs has named Gregg R. Lemkau as a new co-head of global mergers and acquisitions, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

headline: Denon’s New Receiver: Saving Time on Setup?
abstract: Generally the more features, the more complex the setup. The new top-of-the-line Denon AVR-E400 is loaded with features and is no exception to the rule.

headline: Disruptions: Stuck With a Provider Over the Long Haul
abstract: Owning a cellphone on one of the biggest providers can sometimes feel like an unhappy relationship, with companies frequently taking advantage of customers.

headline: Around the World in 80 Days for Cuba’s Most Famous Dissident Blogger
abstract: As Yoani Sanchez started her worldwide book tour, questions swirled — about both her future and her country’s.

headline: At Literature Festival, Yearning for Bollywood Past

headline: OpenTable to Acquire Foodspotting for $10 Million
abstract: Booking a restaurant reservation on the Internet is more convenient than calling a hostess or jotting your name down on a waiting list, but it can feel impersonal. OpenTable, the online reservation business, says it is acquiring a start-up to make booking a table a bit more intimate and social.

headline: Venture Capital’s Sluggish Performance
abstract: Investors need to strip the venture capital industry of its mystique and demand greater transparency and a better deal, the author contends.

headline: Questioning the Motives Behind Your Financial Decisions

headline: A Sensible Change in Taxing Derivatives
abstract: A proposal being considered by Congress would help eliminate a tax loophole on certain financial contracts that some investors have used in order to avoid taxes, the author writes.

abstract: Frugal travel along the Yangtze River, a dad can’t have it all either, answers to questions about paying for college and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Office Depot and OfficeMax Are Said to Be Discussing a Merger

headline: A Race Against Loeb That Left Ackman Breathless

headline: No More, No Less
abstract: The Fed policy debate is shifting from whether to do more to when to do less, though neither course seems likely soon.

headline: Hakon Invest to Buy Stake in Nordic Retailer for $3.1 Billion
abstract: The Swedish company Hakon Invest has agreed to buy the remaining stake in the Nordic retailer ICA that it does not already own for $3.1 billion.

abstract: Our financial situations can be easier to handle with a positive outlook, as long as we don’t get carried away with our optimism.

abstract: For the first time in over a year, median annual income fell by a statistically significant amount from the previous month, according to a report from Sentier Research.

abstract: Bradley Cooper — handsome and environmentally correct — was the latest A-lister to wear green black tie. What would get you to follow his fashion lead?

abstract: The law firm’s move to get out of the estate-planning business comes as the legal industry continues to emphasize more profitable practices.

abstract: Less access to long-term care insurance for women, staying private on the new Facebook, getting texts from your lost luggage and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: How to Make Women’s Service in Combat Roles a Success

abstract: The nation’s largest brick-and-mortar book retailer is warning that it will not meet expectations for another quarter.

abstract: A list of overused medical tests, words to help conversations about bullying, a bigger role for insurance in the gun debate and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: As Research in Motion prepares to introduce the BlackBerry 10, the company has been very cagey about the fees it will charge corporations for using the device’s network. The fees have been an important part of RIM’s profits and analysts are concerned about a possible decline in revenue.

abstract: The prosecution has called half of their 90 witnesses, defense witnesses will be next.

abstract: Junie Hoang, 41, argued that the database illegally used information to obtain her real age, exposing her to age discrimination in Hollywood.

abstract: The hedge fund manager David Einhorn made his name publicly challenging big companies like Lehman Brothers. Here is a look at some of his moments in the spotlight.

abstract: Answers to some basic questions about medical care for pets.

headline: Book Deal for Author Ends Circuitous Path Back to Mainstream
abstract: Thirteen years after her debut novel, “Last Things,” was released, Jenny Offill is returning with a two-book deal with Vintage, a division of Random House.

headline: Sinopec to Raise $3.1 Billion in Hong Kong
abstract: The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, the oil and refining giant better known as Sinopec, said proceeds from the private placement of new shares would be used to finance business development.

abstract: William A. Ackman and Daniel S. Loeb became business rivals on Wednesday, with hundreds of millions of dollars in play over Herbalife. | Diminished profits have forced Morgan Stanley to cut back its trading desk, raising questions about the firm. | Jacob J. Lew, President Obama’s chief of staff and former budget director, has been tapped to be the secretary of the Treasury. | Amid criticism, the board of the American International Group decided not to join a lawsuit against the federal government.

abstract: Something remarkable was under way in southern China on Monday: an open revolt at one of the country’s biggest news groups against the propaganda authorities.

abstract: Can American Giant, a start-up clothing maker, convince people to buy sweatshirts they can’t touch or try on? Will people buy based on images and word of mouth alone?

abstract: Security researchers say that hackers engineered networks of computers in data centers, allowing them to cripple online banking sites in a way that amateurs could not, report Nicole Perlroth and Quentin Hardy. It is a level of skill and sophistication that suggests state-sponsored attacks.

abstract: Shares in the unit of the state-owned Citic Group soared on news of the deal, which would help Citic Telecom expand its business in Greater China and signal an exit from the region for Britain’s Cable & Wireless Communications.

abstract: In Mali, France faces the risk of “mission creep” — the possibility that its involvement could expand and that it might become difficult to end. Even if the military option works in the short term, other steps will be need to ensure stability, analysts say.

abstract: A former junior lawyer at the firm filed a lawsuit against Faruqi & Faruqi on Wednesday, accusing one of its most prominent partners of sexual harassment.

abstract: More people are traveling and more travelers are taking an interest in sustainability. But the cornucopia of certification programs for environmental friendliness can be confusing.

abstract: One cat’s 200-mile journey home, tips for finding rental-car deals, mortgages for fixer-uppers and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

abstract: Microsoft Office 2013 is due soon but if you cannot wait for it, you can buy the current edition now and get a free upgrade to Office 2013 when it arrives.

abstract: Muslim actor Salman Khan turns a much-panned action adventure into a top Bollywood earner.

headline: Another Day, Another Protest on China’s Edges

headline: One on One: John Legere, the Hip New Chief of T-Mobile USA
abstract: T-Mobile USA wants to be the cool wireless carrier for hip people. Its new chief executive, John J. Legere, who wears a T-shirt under his sports coat, seems suited for the job. In an interview, he talked about T-Mobile’s new unlimited plan, which costs $70 a month — no contract required.

headline: Firm Focused on Investing in Lawsuits Brings in Old Leader

abstract: In its Press Freedom Index 2013, the media group Reporters Without Borders finds that Myanmar is surging in Asia, Taiwan is the most free, and Thailand is performing badly.

The attacks appear to be the second wave of a hacking campaign that began in September, when a hacker group calling itself Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Cyber Fighters took credit for a series of attacks on banking sites in retaliation for an anti-Islam video that was posted online in the United States.

headline: Nominee for ‘Sheriff’ Has Worn Banks’ Hat
abstract: Mary Jo White, President Obama’s pick to run the Securities and Exchange Commission, is a former defender of those she’d be expected to oversee.

headline: Shell Denies Tax Evasion in India
abstract: Energy giant accused of evading taxes by India’s income tax department.

headline: About.me Buys Itself Back From AOL
abstract: On Monday, About.me’s co-founders announced that they had purchased their company back from AOL, which originally acquired the company two years ago for tens of millions of dollars.

headline: NELL Is a Computer That Reads the Web – With a Little Human Help
abstract: The Never-Ending Language Learner is a computer that reads the Web and seeks to understand the meaning of words and phrases in context. The project at Carnegie Mellon University, funded by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency and Google, began as a purely automated endeavor, computer algorithms roaming the Web. But it now relies on human helpers as well as algorithms.

headline: Free Tax Preparation Software Available
abstract: For those with income of $57,000 or less, free tax preparation software is available online from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Sexual Offenses Bill to Be Altered to Pass Parliament
abstract: Definition of voyeurism and stalking expected to be watered down.

headline: Intel’s Big Data Push
abstract: The world’s largest maker of semiconductors has released its own version of an open source database designed for Big Data analysis, meant for easy use by mainstream companies.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 29
abstract: A mortar strike at Damascus University; the Taliban in Karachi; Hong Kong keeps an eye on a new virus; a new theory about fairy circles; and Helen Mirren and Judi Dench take on the West End.

headline: Barbara Walters to Return to ‘The View’
abstract: After more than a month sidelined with chicken pox, Ms. Walters will return to the hit ABC daytime show starting next week.

headline: Thursday Reading: Finding Frugal Gems in Chongqing
abstract: Finding frugal gems in Chongqing, why you should buy LED light bulbs, camouflage goes trendy and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Strong Calls for Change on Eve of China’s National Congress
abstract: As China’s Parliament, the National People’s Congress, opens Tuesday, some are calling for changes to the re-education-through-labor system, which one delegate said causes citizens to “live in fear.”

headline: Lloyds Banking Reports a $2.2 Billion Annual Loss
abstract: The British banking group’s results were hit by a $2.3 billion charge in the fourth quarter related to compensation for customers that were inappropriately sold insurance products.

headline: Andrew Sullivan on Going Back to Future as an Indie Blogger
abstract: Andrew Sullivan talks about new media’s new Darwinism and making at least some readers pay.

headline: R.B.S. Fine a Burden for the Bank’s Majority Owner, British Taxpayers
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland’s $612 million settlement with authorities over rate manipulation leaves British taxpayers liable for part of the fine.

headline: BlackRock Posts Record Profit as Investors Take On More Risk
abstract: In the last quarter, the money manager’s customers opted for stocks or equities instead of the lower-risk bond investments that they had favored since the financial crisis.

headline: R.B.S. Executives Testify in Rate-Rigging Case
abstract: British politicians sharply questioned current and former executives of the Royal Bank of Scotland on Monday about the management failures that led to the rate-manipulation scandal.

headline: Sternlicht’s Starwood to Buy Distressed Debt Manager for $1.05 Billion
abstract: The Starwood Capital Group and Starwood Property Trust, both run by Barry S. Sternlicht, agreed on Thursday to pay $1.05 billion for LNR Property, bolstering their positions in distressed commercial real estate.

headline: Ryanair Indicates Regulators Will Reject Aer Lingus Deal
abstract: Ryanair, the discount European airline, said on Tuesday that it planned to appeal should regulators block its bid for Aer Lingus.

headline: Wealthy Russians Ensnared as Cyprus Crisis Deepens
abstract: About 25 percent of Russian foreign direct investment moves through Cyprus, according to an estimate, often in a way meant to lubricate Russia’s economy.

headline: PPR to Show Breton Roots With Rebranding as Kering
abstract: The Paris luxury house, whose brands include Gucci, Balenciaga and Puma, said it was changing its name to Kering, a word based on the Breton for “home.”

headline: Myanmar Troops Sent to City Torn by Sectarian Rioting
abstract: At least 20 people have died in clashes between Buddhists and Muslims outside a city in central Myanmar, according to residents, a member of Parliament and local journalists.

headline: Pakistan Says U.S. Drone Strike Kills 4
abstract: The attack hit a vehicle in northwestern Pakistan late on Thursday night, government officials said.

headline: From Disney, a Video Game Universe on One Platform
abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

abstract: A critique of the Super Bowl ads finds them wanting; Legendary Entertainment, run by a Hollywood outsider, gets a large piece of the blockbuster movie season; and the FX channel embraces the dark side of storytelling.

abstract: David Pogue walks the floor of the International Consumer Electronics Show and finds humor in the excess — mostly of it unintended by the companies.

abstract: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: Zimbabwe: Human Rights Lawyer Released From Jail
abstract: Beatrice Mtetwa had been held on a charge of obstruction of justice after demanding a search warrant at a client’s home.

headline: Petrobras, Once Symbol of Brazil’s Oil Hopes, Strives to Regain Lost Swagger
abstract: Once a symbol of Brazil’s rise as a global oil powerhouse, Petrobras, the national oil company, now embodies the sluggishness of the economy itself.

headline: Focus on Healing Arts After Kidnapping Conviction
abstract: Tomás Cassella, a former Uruguayan Army colonel who was extradited to Chile in 2006, has become a reiki master, but is living in legal limbo as he appeals his case.

headline: Syrian Rebels Hit Central Damascus Square With Mortar Shells
abstract: At least one person was killed, state media reported, in some of the worst shelling in the heart of Damascus since the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad began two years ago.

headline: Prisoner X of Israel Is Said to Have Exposed Top Spies
abstract: Two news organizations have reported that the man, Ben Zygier, unintentionally revealed the identities of two top spies for Israel in Lebanon to a man known to be close to Hezbollah.

abstract: A landmark case, involving a Filipino woman who had worked in Hong Kong for 27 years as a domestic helper, highlighted questions of judicial independence.

abstract: In more than 300 e-mail replies on whether to allow pen knives on planes, many of the strongest supporters of the rule change were women who travel for business.

abstract: The emir of Qatar, Sheik Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, said he would contribute $250 million toward the fund, aimed at protecting Jerusalem’s Arab and Islamic legacy.

abstract: An account of how the United States came to use a drone strike to kill the American-born terrorist leader Anwar al-Awlaki highlights the perils of a war conducted behind a classified veil.

abstract: North Koreans have said many times over the years that they were disregarding the armistice ending the Korean War. What is unclear this time is whether they mean it.

abstract: A report released Tuesday found a catalog of police failures that allowed Jimmy Savile, a television personality, to avoid investigation for a lifetime of sex offenses.

abstract: Anhar Kochneva told a Russian radio station that after being held by a Syrian rebel group since October, she “just walked out and left.”

abstract: Many institutions, including Ivy League universities and unheralded community colleges, offer older students free or discounted tuition.

abstract: While flamenco remains a quintessential component of Spanish culture, its economic sustainability relies increasingly on foreigners, who flock to Andalusia to learn the dance and its music.

abstract: The cash shortage is raising questions about Egypt’s ability to keep importing wheat that is essential to the food supply, stirring fears of an economic catastrophe.

abstract: Turkey’s threat to prosecute or expel 130 refugees, and Israel’s growing concerns about injured Syrians coming across the border, are the latest signs of how Syria’s war has destabilized the region.

headline: U.S. Runs Practice Sortie in South Korea
abstract: The rare announcement that the United States military ran a practice bombing sortie over South Korea underscores Washington’s commitment to defend its ally amid rising tensions with North Korea.

abstract: Relief that bank doors were open again mixed with anxiety over new rules that allow customers to make deposits but tightly ration out the money already in accounts.

abstract: It was the third time in four months that Nelson Mandela, 94, South Africa’s first black president, has been hospitalized.

abstract: Sprint Nextel and SoftBank, its Japanese suitor, are expected to accept restrictions from American law enforcement officials on the companies’ ability to pick telecommunications suppliers.

abstract: China wants a railroad linking it to Thailand and on to the Bay of Bengal in Myanmar, but some international groups warn that it may put a big burden on Laos.

abstract: A new willingness to talk raises hope of a peaceful resolution to a conflict that has driven thousands of civilians from their homes in search of refuge.

abstract: Executives made frequent trips to Washington to press their case in an antitrust inquiry, laying out legal arguments and applying lessons from Microsoft’s bruising 1990s battle.

abstract: Airstrikes alone may not be enough to root out battle-hardened Malian rebels, who have spent months accumulating arms, constructing defenses and reinforcing their ranks.

abstract: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India claimed Pakistan beheaded an Indian soldier in the Kashmir region, an action he said had halted cooperation between the two countries.

abstract: The F.D.A. released a sharply worded warning letter to St. Jude Medical in which it said it might soon fine the company for failing to address agency concerns.

abstract: Maria Alyokhina had asked to be released temporarily so that she could be with her young son, but a judge in Siberia rejected the appeal.

abstract: Anti-establishment parties are hoping to draw on the widespread anger and skepticism toward Italy’s old guard, but investors and Italy’s European Union partners worry about instability if no clear winner emerges.

headline: Merkel Raises Turks’ Hope Of European Union Entry
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has called for talks between Turkey and the European Union amid signals of decreasing resistance from her center-right party.

headline: In Cyberspace, New Cold War
abstract: The Obama administration is escalating demands that China halt the state-sponsored computer hack attacks that Beijing insists it is not mounting.

headline: Anemia Drug Is Recalled After Allergic Reactions
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said it had received 19 reports of a severe allergic reaction to the drug, Omontys, and that three of the patients had died.

headline: Nearly 100 Rebels Are Reported Killed in Mali Battle
abstract: Chad’s military said it had lost 23 soldiers in the firefight, apparently the deadliest ground encounter of the war.

headline: Old Homosexuality Laws Still Hang Over Many in Germany
abstract: Roughly 50,000 men persecuted for homosexuality after World War II have yet to have the convictions stricken from their police records. But that could change in an election year.

headline: Gay Wedding Is Embraced by Disney in Tokyo
abstract: A gay rights activist who chronicled her wedding planning and ceremony online was married on Friday in an event that drew largely positive responses on Twitter.

headline: Britain Takes On Brussels in Fight Over Bank Pay
abstract: The British finance minister, George Osborne, is expected Tuesday to urge his European Union counterparts to water down proposed rules restricting the size of bankers' bonuses.

headline: Gaza Marathon Canceled After Women Are Barred From Participating
abstract: The decision came after Hamas leaders informed the race’s organizer, a United Nations agency, that women would not be allowed to take part under any circumstances.

headline: Concerns About Politics Overshadow an Auto Show
abstract: Amid the new models at the auto show, fresh reasons to fear for the health of the long-suffering European market.

headline: Clothing Companies Trying to Find More Direct Paths to Customers
abstract: Many new apparel brands have decided to forgo the traditional wholesale route of selling through multibrand boutiques and department stores, but it is not for everyone.

headline: Fire in Senegal Kills Child Beggars Trapped in House
abstract: At least nine children died in a fire in Dakar, including seven boys who beg and study the Koran under the guidance of a holy man.

headline: In Last Sunday Address, Pope Says He Will Continue to Serve God
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI says he will continue to serve and love the church by praying and meditating after his abdication on Thursday.

headline: Palestinians Dispute Israel’s Findings on a Prisoner’s Death
abstract: Israeli authorities said the 30-year-old prisoner died of a heart attack, but Palestinian officials said he was tortured during his interrogation in an Israeli jail.

headline: From Disney, a Video Game Universe on One Platform
abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

headline: In Heinz Takeover, a New Path for Deals
abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

headline: Tell Us: Employer Benefits for Same-Sex Couples
abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

abstract: A case brought by the founders of Dragon Systems was among a spate of legal problems and public relations headaches for Goldman in recent years.

abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.

abstract: David Pogue walks the floor of the International Consumer Electronics Show and finds humor in the excess — mostly of it unintended by the companies.

abstract: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: Think New York Is Costly? In New Delhi, Seedy Goes for 8 Figures
abstract: Real estate prices in New Delhi, especially for bungalows built during the British Raj, are among the world’s highest.

headline: Two Afghan Boys Accidentally Killed by NATO Helicopter
abstract: Two boys out collecting firewood with their donkeys were killed by weapons fired from a NATO helicopter, Afghan and American military officials announced on Saturday.

headline: New Chinese Leader Shores Up Military Support
abstract: On the eve of the opening of the National People’s Congress, Xi Jinping is using the armed forces to cement his political authority and present a tough stance by China in growing territorial disputes.

headline: Assad and British Official Trade Verbal Blows Over Syrian Conflict
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad criticized British aid for rebels in Syria, but Britain’s foreign secretary, William Hague, called Mr. Assad’s view of the conflict “delusional.”

headline: Chad Said to Have Killed Mastermind of Algerian Attack
abstract: Mokhtar Belmokhtar’s death was announced on state television in Chad, but the claim has not been confirmed.

headline: Seized Chinese Weapons Raise Concerns on Iran
abstract: The presence of 10 Chinese heat-seeking missiles in an arms cache seized by American and Yemeni officials sets off concerns about further regional instability.

abstract: As Italian voters head to the polls on Sunday and Monday to elect the Parliament and three regional governments, the mood is one of anger and disillusionment.

headline: Swollen With Syrian Refugees, Lebanon Feels Its Stitching Fray
abstract: An influx of needy Syrians, seeming to fill Lebanon’s every nook and cranny, is heightening sectarian tensions in a nation haunted by refugee crises and loath to act.

headline: French Intervention in Mali Raises Threat of Domestic Terrorism, Judge Says
abstract: Some French citizens of black African ancestry have become more willing to fight under the banner of jihad, according to France’s most prominent investigative judge dealing with terrorism.

headline: In-Law Says Spain’s Royal Family Had No Business Role
abstract: A princess’s husband testified in a fraud investigation that neither King Juan Carlos nor others in the household offered him advice about a foundation he ran.

headline: Kerry Vows Not to Leave Syria Rebels ‘Dangling in the Wind’
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said the Obama administration was mulling new steps to increase support for the Syrian opposition and hasten the departure of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: At 125 Years, a Rechristening for The Herald Tribune
abstract: The New York Times Company said it was planning to rename The International Herald Tribune, its 125-year-old newspaper based in Paris, and would also redesign its Web site for international audiences.

headline: One More Trip to Land of Oz
abstract: Disney’s movie studio, which has stumbled recently, takes a bold risk with a prequel to the beloved 1939 musical, “The Wizard of Oz.”

headline: General Says Killing of Militant in Mali Is Not Confirmed
abstract: The commander of Chad’s troops in an operation with the French says that the fate of the Islamist leader Mokhtar Belmokhtar was still unknown.

headline: Bangkok’s Governor Re-elected, Signaling Thailand’s Political Split
abstract: Defying predictions by pollsters, Gov. Sukhumbhand Paribatra retained his post, winning a hard-fought election against a candidate from the party of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.

headline: At Least 19 Killed as Unrest Persists in Bangladesh
abstract: Angry skirmishes over convictions by a war crimes tribunal entered another day, with several deaths.

headline: Guardian Aims to Turn American Readers’ Heads

abstract: Many companies are borrowing money for projects using tax-exempt bonds called qualified private activity bonds, costing federal taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Report Blames Climate Change for Extremes in Australia
abstract: A government report argues that the frequency and ferocity of recent extreme weather events demands action to prevent further changes to the environment.

headline: Chinese Stocks Plunge on Plan to Tax Home Sales

abstract: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao delivered a sometimes gloomy assessment of the state of Chinese society in his final annual work report to the national legislature.

headline: Georgian Sees Closer Ties With Russia
abstract: The country’s new prime minister, Bidzina Ivanishvili, said Tuesday that he was making progress on a campaign promise: repairing badly frayed relations with Russia.

headline: Syrian Insurgents Claim to Control Large Hydropower Dam
abstract: The Tabqa Dam, Syria’s biggest, is considered a potent weapon in the battle for allegiances in the nearly two-year-old conflict.

headline: Shell Vessels Sidelined, Imperiling Arctic Plans
abstract: The company’s ambitious oil exploration program in the Arctic has been hindered by delays for the last seven years.

headline: Russia: Explosion in Coal Mine Kills at Least 17
abstract: An explosion in a coal mine in northern Russia killed at least 17 miners in a shaft saturated with methane gas, rescue workers said Monday.

headline: Ruling Islamists, Under Attack, Reject Blame for Tunisia’s Woes
abstract: Facing public anger and internal divisions after the assassination of an opposition leader, the Ennahda party did not seem to look inward.

headline: Airline Industry at Its Safest Since the Dawn of the Jet Age
abstract: It will be four years on Tuesday since the last fatal crash in the United States, a record unmatched since propeller planes gave way to the jet.

headline: Critics of Executive Pay Put Pressure on Novartis
abstract: The drug maker plans to pay Daniel Vasella, its departing chairman, $78 million to prevent him from sharing knowledge with competitors.

headline: Draghi Seeks to Ease Talk of Global Currency War
abstract: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, urged financial officials not to say anything that would contribute to fears of a global currency war.

headline: Fuel Surcharges Push Up International Airfares
abstract: A wave of discounts for air travel has faded in the face of the rising cost of fuel and dwindling capacity.

headline: Yemen, Hailed as Model, Struggles for Stability
abstract: In some ways, the country’s transition has achieved relative calm two years since the start of its uprising, yet many Yemenis doubt anything substantial has changed.

headline: Iran: Rivals Forced to Apologize to Supreme Leader
abstract: Rival politicians apologized to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei over the weekend for having been embroiled in an unusually public feud involving secret tapes and a tit-for-tat impeachment.

abstract: An overwhelming percentage of the attacks on American companies and government agencies start in a building on the edge of Shanghai, say cybersecurity experts and American intelligence officials.

abstract: With President Obama apparently running out of ways to speed President Bashar al-Assad’s exit,  American officials may revive a debate on giving weapons to his opponents.

abstract: Pharmaceutical companies are helping to develop tests for illicit use in order to keep their offerings from being abused by athletes.

abstract: With some states poised to clear the way for legal gambling on the Internet, Silicon Valley’s traditional gaming companies are expanding to meet the expected deluge of players.

abstract: The vote showed the broad popularity of President Rafael Correa’s government’s social programs and support for the poor.

abstract: President Shimon Peres plans to give President Obama a special award at a state dinner next month when Mr. Obama is expected to visit Israel.

abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said that Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan had made “objectionable” remarks when he cast Zionism as a crime against humanity in comments at a United Nations meeting.

headline: Italian Lender Sues Deutsche Bank and Nomura
abstract: In a first attempt to retrieve some of its losses, Monte dei Paschi di Siena sued Deutsche Bank and Nomura over certain financial transactions that went bad.

abstract: As Lagos tries to raise its business profile, the city’s poor feel they have become the government’s enemy, a feeling deepened by the dismantling of a slum last week.

abstract: At least three people were killed and seven people were injured in a shooting at a Swiss factory on Wednesday, the police said, adding that the gunman was among the dead.

headline: Foes Want Czech Leader Prosecuted Over Amnesty
abstract: Opponents try to press charges of high treason over President Vaclav Klaus’s granting of amnesty to people accused of corruption.

abstract: Beppe Grillo, a leading political force after the election, ruled out joining a government alliance, a step that experts said would prolong uncertainty.

abstract: The court said that a class-action lawsuit against Amgen could stand, and it imposed a strict time limit on some suits filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

abstract: Elba Esther Gordillo was arrested on suspicion of embezzling $200 million in union funds for her personal use.

abstract: An agreement between the Thai government and the Barisan Revolusi Nasional to hold negotiations was a hopeful but tentative sign that tensions may ease in a deadly insurgency.
