abstract: Malaysian security forces battled on Friday morning with about 180 Filipinos in an effort to remove them from a remote coastal village, leaving at least 13 people dead.

abstract: The Swiss are set to vote on a proposal that would give shareholders a binding say on compensation for executives and board members.

abstract: A live television show on China’s national broadcaster on Friday displayed four foreign drug traffickers, convicted of murder, being led to their executions.

abstract: Corporate America has historically been slow to take up civil rights issues, but companies have rushed to show support for same-sex marriage.

abstract: A German television crew filming in a village near Beijing was assaulted by men in four vehicles who tried to run the crew’s minivan off the road, said one of the correspondents.

abstract: Ryan Smith, the chief executive of Qualtrics, says his company has a transparent culture because “everyone needs to know where we are going and how we are going to get there.”

abstract: In the widening world of classes taught online, new technologies are helping to ensure that students on distant laptops are doing their own work.

abstract: The government now backs about 90 percent of new home mortgages. A new report outlines a plan for getting the private sector more involved.

abstract: Thousands of homeowners who received help on their second mortgage are still facing foreclosure on their first mortgage, according to housing advocates.

abstract: The investor, author and analyst had a history of accurately predicting the stock market.

headline: Borough Searches for Missing Boy, Last Seen on Wall
abstract: A work by the graffiti artist Banksy that appeared on a wall in Haringey, a borough of London, was ripped out, appearing next in an art auction in Miami.

abstract: The World Health Organization, cautioning that its report is based on early information, says that continued monitoring is necessary.

abstract: The easing was portrayed as part of an effort to strengthen the fragile government’s authority by permitting it to purchase light weapons.

abstract: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy has sent a signal, through friends quoted in an article to be published on Thursday, of his supposedly reluctant willingness to return to politics.

abstract: The rejection at a major international conference  highlighted the difficulties of reaching a global consensus on protecting many kinds of endangered wildlife.

abstract: A resolution in response to North Korea’s nuclear test last month, negotiated between the United States and China, won unanimous approval from the United Nations Security Council.

abstract: Malaysian security forces killed 31 Filipino gunmen on Borneo Island, officials said, and the government rejected calls by the United Nations for an end to the fighting.

abstract: Facebook plans to announce a substantial redesign of its News Feed — a makeover aimed both at keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars.

abstract: The princes of the Roman Catholic Church chose March 12 to begin secret voting for a successor to Benedict XVI, who set the transition in motion by resigning the papacy.

abstract: Uhuru Kenyatta appeared to have secured enough votes to win the race for Kenya’s presidency by a narrow margin, but his opponent’s rejection of the result raised fears of chaos.

abstract: At least four people were killed in what appeared to be a knife fight, officials said, in a region where ethnic Uighur bridle at what they call discrimination by the Han Chinese.

abstract: The joblessness rate sank to 7.7 percent as 236,000 positions were added across a broad range of sectors, but analysts warned that federal budget cuts could slow the recovery.

abstract: The funeral was a stunning display of the political alliances that President Hugo Chávez assembled while in power, including some of those with a history of difficult relations with Washington.

abstract: Two Canadian convicts shimmied up a rope at a provincial detention center north of Montreal to a helicopter hijacked by two accomplices, but they were back in custody a day later.

abstract: Farmers are receiving record prices for their land — but economists and banking regulators warn this boom, like so many before it, could end badly.

abstract: Lawmakers on Monday were said to have struck a deal on new regulations for newspapers, potentially one of the strongest peacetime press curbs in three centuries.

abstract: The attack at the court complex in Peshawar in northwest Pakistan on Monday also wounded at least 30 people, including a judge.

abstract: The stapler remains the one office tool that gives the satisfying click of a job that’s done.

abstract: News Corporation wants the F.C.C. to waive a rule that would prevent it from acquiring The Los Angeles Times, but a regulator’s exit may delay further action.

abstract: It is still unclear how Boris A. Berezovsky died, but what is certain is that a humiliating court ruling last August helped to drive the exiled oligarch into despair.

abstract: Jay Leno is still the ratings king of late-night television, but his expected replacement, Jimmy Fallon, has Internet skills and cross-generational appeal.

abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry urged the government to make public the results of an investigation of what happened to Sombath Somphone, an American-educated agricultural specialist.

abstract: Military help for Syria’s opposition from Arab states and Turkey has grown in recent months, and the C.I.A.’s role has indicated an American willingness to help support lethal aid.

abstract: In Loppersum, the Netherlands, residents fear an increase in earthquakes from drilling for natural gas.

abstract: Facing a Monday deadline to avoid a banking collapse, Cyprus and its negotiators devised a plan Saturday to take a percentage of savers’ deposits above 100,000 euros to raise money for a bailout.

abstract: The most common image of an innovator is of a kid developing a great idea in a garage. But that is the exception to the rule.

abstract: Sergei Udaltsov, leader of the radical socialist Left Front movement, faces a charge of conspiracy to incite mass disorder and faces up to 10 years in prison.

abstract: The raid was carried out to check residency permits and eliminate networks of religious extremists, officials said.

abstract: Brokers used to promote bad investments mainly to people trying to get rich quick, but with traditional portfolios losing value, more ordinary retirement savers are being duped.

abstract: Several journalists who write about Myanmar have received warnings from Google that their Gmail accounts may have been hacked by “state-sponsored attackers.”

abstract: Although 30 seconds of commercial time on the Oscars broadcast sold for $1.65 million to $1.8 million, demand was the strongest “in over a decade,” ABC said.

abstract: A blast on Thursday near the Damascus headquarters of President Bashar al-Assad’s ruling party killed mostly civilians but also security forces, opposition sources said.

headline: New Leader of China Plans a Visit to Moscow
abstract: The Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, has selected Moscow as his first foreign visit as president, to be followed immediately by a trip to South Africa.

abstract: Iran reached an agreement on Tuesday with world powers to resume the stuttering dialogue over its disputed nuclear program later this month in Kazakhstan, officials said.

abstract: For nearly 300 years, the Richard Ginori factory produced singular, handcrafted and elegant porcelain tableware, but the factory was declared bankrupt in January.

abstract: A federal suit paints Standard & Poor’s as willing to cut corners to keep its customers — much as the accounting firm did in the Enron scandal.

abstract: The police suspect arson in the blaze at the offices of Beitar Jerusalem, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu condemned protests by soccer fans over the addition of the Muslim players.

headline: Following a Herd of Bulls on Apple
abstract: Even with reforms meant to reduce conflicts of interest, many analysts failed to foresee a plunge in Apple’s shares.

abstract: A series of explosions struck across Iraq amid worsening sectarian tensions before elections in April.

abstract: Russia has a reputation for crazy motorists and stupefying traffic accidents, leading many drivers to install dashboard cameras, which document every minute on the road.

abstract: An Indian Army statement said Indian soldiers returned fire from an intruder and later found a dead Pakistani soldier, whose body has been returned.

headline: Iran: Pistachio Exports Are Suspended
abstract: Pistachio nuts, one of Iran’s most profitable products, appear to be latest victim of domestic inflation, so much so that the government has ordered a moratorium on exports.

abstract: New data show uneven benefits from the economic recovery of 2010-11, with a big rise for the highest earners and little change for others.

abstract: A deal involving Bank of America that came to light recently shows how bank bailouts have continued, even if in a much quieter form than in the depths of the financial crisis.

abstract: The decision to drop wrestling from the 2020 Olympics hits hard in Iran, where the sport is deeply embedded in the national cultural narrative.

abstract: As chief of the large Russian energy company, Mr. Vyakhirev resisted efforts by Russian reformers to break up and privatize it.

abstract: A day after a leading opposition figure was assassinated, Tunisia’s dominant party said it opposed a plan to dissolve the government, according to news reports.

abstract: An international meeting on Libya that was held in Paris focused on border control, weapon-smuggling and challenges posed by regional militias that have not disarmed.

abstract: The first rule for would-be video bloggers: Don’t let your ego get between the camera and the audience.

abstract: A top European Union official has called on the steel maker to delay moves to reduce operations, but the Indian company has refused.

abstract: Dov Lipman is both an ultra-Orthodox rabbi and a newly elected member of Parliament who is hoping to help bridge the divisions between the secular and ultra-Orthodox in Israel.

abstract: The devaluation will set the bolívar at 6.3 instead of 4.3 to the dollar. The expected move was aimed at solidifying government finances and easing a tight market for dollars.

abstract: An environmental agency’s report says United States companies send spent lead batteries to recycling plants in Mexico that do not meet American standards.

abstract: Hanergy Holding Group of China added to its international acquisitions with MiaSolé, a thin-film solar panel manufacturer that is considered one of Silicon Valley’s most promising young firms.

abstract: In an attempt to prevent future housing crises, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is issuing new laws for lenders.

abstract: There appears to be broad support for gay unions in France, but when it comes to marriage, it may be another matter.

abstract: The Basque nationalist political party, Batasuna, already illegal in Spain, announced Thursday that it would dissolve itself in France as well.

abstract: As the island of Giglio prepares to commemorate the anniversary of the wreck on Sunday, environmentalists worry that the longer the delay, the greater the environmental risk.

abstract: Foreign lenders say Greece has fallen short of its tax collection targets and is still not moving hard enough to tackle widespread, long-tolerated tax evasion.

abstract: The United States’ 13 public stock exchanges have been competing to offer the fastest and most sophisticated trading software, creating more opportunities for technology errors.

abstract: The United States department said Iranians were using private exchange houses and trading companies in other countries, masking transactions with fake identities and transferring money informally and often illegally through couriers.

abstract: The spokesman for President Vladimir V. Putin said adoptions already approved by a court would be honored, despite a ban on American adoptions signed into law last month.

abstract: Negotiations between rebels and the government, now seem in danger of not happening, as both sides appear to be rearming.

abstract: The government blamed foreign meddling in dismissing the document, which was meant to help the coup-plagued nation return to democracy ahead of elections set for next year.

abstract: The money will go toward public works projects, small businesses and subsidies for companies that invest in new technology.

abstract: Computer algorithms are capable of trading stocks, arranging dates and winning “Jeopardy.” But increasingly, behind the curtain, there is a human helper.

headline: Uprooted by Tsunami, Church’s Flock Regroups
abstract: The Fukushima First Baptist Church, whose members fled after the March 2011 disaster, has had a long road back.

headline: South Korea Flirts With Nuclear Ideas as North Blusters
abstract: North Korea’s threats of war have led to a new sense of vulnerability among South Koreans that is causing some to push for a nuclear arsenal in their country.

headline: Syria Military Shows Strain in a War It Wasn’t Built to Fight
abstract: The conflict has pushed a military built for repelling an Israeli invasion, not carrying out sustained asymmetrical combat, to scale back its goals and rethink its tactics.

headline: Honest Tea Creates a Business Guide as a Comic Book
abstract: The beverage maker Honest Tea has aimed to help start-ups by telling its tale of missteps and successes in an accessible format.

headline: Conflict in Northern Borneo Seems Poised to Escalate
abstract: A Filipino group seeks to recapture Malaysian territory once belonging to the Sultanate of Sulu.

headline: Karzai Bets on Vilifying U.S. to Shed His Image as a Lackey
abstract: In what is expected to be his final year in office, President Hamid Karzai is intensifying his criticism of his American allies at a critical moment in their Afghan endgame.

headline: Condé Nast Adds to Job of Longtime Vogue Editor
abstract: As the magazine company’s artistic director, Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, will take over some responsibilities once held by S. I. Newhouse Jr.

headline: Singapore Pledges Inquiry Into Death of an American Engineer
abstract: After a meeting with United States Senator Max Baucus, Singapore’s foreign minister said his country would investigate the death of Shane Todd, who police say died of a suicide.

abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

abstract: A case brought by the founders of Dragon Systems was among a spate of legal problems and public relations headaches for Goldman in recent years.

abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.

abstract: David Pogue walks the floor of the International Consumer Electronics Show and finds humor in the excess — mostly of it unintended by the companies.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: Industry Shifts With Dell Deal
abstract: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: Negotiators for Arms Trade Treaty Discuss Regulation of Ammunition
abstract: Negotiators at the United Nations began a final round of talks on Monday aimed at completing a treaty to regulate the international trade in conventional weapons.

headline: China: More Pigs Found in River
abstract: The number of dead pigs found in the river near Shanghai rose to more than 13,000 over the weekend.

headline: Seeking Profit for Taxpayers in Potential of New Drug
abstract: Congress wants a second look at how private firms profit from public research after Pfizer and the National Institutes of Health developed a potentially lucrative new drug.

headline: Doctors Urge F.D.A. to Restrict Caffeine in Energy Drinks
abstract: Caffeine levels in the drinks “pose serious potential health risks,” specifically to children and young adults, according to a letter from 18 doctors and public health experts.

headline: Iraqis’ Pain Never Abates as Attacks Kill Dozens
abstract: Nineteen bombs and an assassination on Tuesday served as a reminder of the violence that regularly afflicts Iraq a decade after the American-led invasion.

headline: Debating Chávez’s Legacy
abstract: While poverty went down significantly during Hugo Chávez’s years as president, Venezuela ranked 13th of 18 countries in per capita economic growth from 1999 to 2011.

headline: Regulator Expresses Doubts About an Auditor’s Procedures
abstract: The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board said that it found problems with procedures at PricewaterhouseCoopers in 2008 and 2009 and that they had not been remedied.

headline: Yes, We’re Confident, but Who Knows Why
abstract: History shows that public confidence is fickle and little understood, but it can have great influence on the markets and the economy.

headline: A Little of This, a Little of That for Older Exercisers
abstract: Activities that mix strength-building and cardiovascular, or aerobic, exercise, can help older people meet physical activity guidelines.

headline: North Korea Declares 1953 War Truce Nullified
abstract: The move to cancel the armistice followed through on a longstanding threat, and came as the United States and South Korea were in the midst of joint military drills.

headline: India Rape Suspect’s Family Says His Death Wasn’t Suicide
abstract: Ram Singh, the driver of a bus in which a 23-year-old woman was fatally gang raped, was found hanging from a ceiling grill on Monday, jail officials said.

headline: Before Smoke Rises at Vatican, It’s Romans vs. the Reformers
abstract: Beneath an orderly display, the cardinals at the papal conclave are split into competing lineups and power blocs that will determine who among them emerges as pope.

headline: Going to College at 65, and Going Greek as Well
abstract: Jerry Reid, who enrolled in college at 65 and joined a fraternity, tells of his experiences as an older student on campus.

headline: Opposition Leader Will Seek Venezuelan Presidency
abstract: Henrique Capriles Radonski, 42, will run against Nicolás Maduro, Mr. Chávez’s handpicked successor, in an election scheduled for April 14.

headline: A Conference With Dual Constituencies Vows to Improve
abstract: An advertising group’s decision to combine conferences is still striving to appeal to all of the attendees, who come from media agencies and the management and creative realms.

headline: In China, New Premier Says He Seeks a Just Society
abstract: In his first comments as prime minister, Li Keqiang offered a tantalizing palette of economic and social reforms that promised to transform the lives of the rural poor, migrants flooding into the cities and retirees.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.

headline: In Effort to Try Dictator, Guatemala Shows New Judicial Might
abstract: After long delays, the former military dictator Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, under whose rule tens of thousands of villagers were killed in a civil war against leftists, is set to stand trial.

headline: The Cossacks Are Back. May the Hills Tremble.
abstract: Revered as fierce horsemen who once secured an empire’s frontier, Cossacks are gaining an increasing role in law enforcement in a newly conservative, nationalist Russia.

headline: Kenyan Court Asked to Order New Election For President
abstract: Raila Odinga, the second-place finisher in Kenya’s presidential race this month, filed a sweeping petition before Kenya’s Supreme Court on Saturday contending “glaring anomalies” in the vote and calling for a new election.

headline: 2 Years Late, Zimbabwe Votes on New Constitution
abstract: The new charter is meant to resolve some of the problems that have kept Zimbabwe mired in crisis, but critics say it leaves the president’s powers undiluted.

headline: A Weather Report That’s Colorful, With a Chance of Fun
abstract: A new kind of weather reporting app provides forecasts that are easy to understand and filled with usable information.

headline: With Worries for Its Economic Future, Cuba Bids a Sad Goodbye to a Generous Ally
abstract: The death of Hugo Chávez, the Venezuelan leader, sent a ripple of sadness and uncertainty across Cuba, which has long relied on Venezuela’s hefty oil subsidies.

headline: Television’s ‘C.S.I.’ Gets New Financial Partner to Replace Goldman
abstract: Content Partners has agreed to buy half of the franchise from a unit of Goldman Sachs in a deal that makes it a co-owner with CBS.

headline: Hoping to Save Bees, Europe to Vote on Pesticide Ban
abstract: European officials plan to vote on a proposal to sharply restrict the use of chemicals that have been implicated in the decline of global bee populations.

headline: Seeking to Aid Rebels in Syria, France Urges End to Arms Embargo
abstract: France joined Britain in urging its European Union partners to meet this month and take action to help the Syrian opposition.

headline: Challenging Management (but Not the Market)
abstract: The investing style of Dimensional Fund Advisors, run by David Booth, is sometimes called passive, but the firm is often an extremely active shareholder in companies in its portfolio.

headline: Entrenched Troubles at Vatican Await a New Pope
abstract: The choice of a New World pope sent messages about the Roman Catholic Church: that its future lies in the global south and that a scholar with a common touch may inspire its faithful.

headline: Boeing Plan to Test Fixes on 787 Nears Approval
abstract: Battery tests on the 787 Dreamliner could begin next week, officials said, but federal regulators could still demand changes in the proposed design changes if problems develop.

headline: Japan’s New Leader Takes On Old Order to Jolt Economy
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is showing a willingness to challenge some of the pillars of Japan’s establishment and sail “the rough seas of global competition.”

headline: J.&J. Loses First Case Over Faulty Hip Implant
abstract: A jury ordered $8.3 million in damages in the first of some 10,000 lawsuits tied to a now-recalled implant.

headline: In China, Checklist for a Home Seller: First, Get a Divorce
abstract: Divorce filings spiked in big cities across China after rumors that one way to avoid a 20 percent tax on profits from housing sales was to separate from a spouse, at least on paper.

headline: Japan Moves to Enter Talks on Pacific Trade
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe portrayed the Trans-Pacific Partnership as Japan’s “last chance” to remain an economic power in Asia.

abstract: Coca-Cola has said it is cooperating with Chinese authorities who are investigating whether its employees engaged in illegal mapping using GPS devices in Yunnan Province.

abstract: Evitan que al general Moisés García Ochoa se convierta en Ministro de Defensa. Funcionarios americanos expresaron preocupación de que tuviera vínculos con narcotraficantes.

abstract: Relational Investors, the activist investment firm run by Ralph V. Whitworth, says that “Elliott’s suggestions for unlocking value are similar to our recommendations.”

abstract: Anna Wintour becomes Condé Nast’s artistic director, NPR reaches out to a younger audience and extensive police failings allowed Jimmy Savile to escape investigation for decades of sexual abuse.

abstract: A Supreme Court decision involving a statute of limitations rule may mean the S.E.C. will need to seek legislation from Congress that would give the agency more time to complete investigations.

abstract: The popular talent show dropped in the category advertisers care most about, continuing the falloff from the huge ratings of earlier seasons.

abstract: Presidents Kennedy and Johnson once embraced the tax-cut policies now supported by the Republican Party (which objected to them at the time), an economist writes.

abstract: Nearly three years after filing to go public, the retailer, which is backed by private equity, has decided to pull back from a market debut.

abstract: Despite all the talk of the 99 percent versus the 1 percent, the “class war” apparently abated last year, if you believe the American public.

abstract: College graduates earn more per hour than high school graduates. But they are also more likely to be employed, and probably more likely to work the number of hours they wish.

abstract: New “bio toilets” and wi-fi among improvements pending for India’s railways.

abstract: In 2006, some executives at Standard & Poor’s pushed to revise the firm’s rating models in hopes of preserving market share, while others expressed deep concerns about the poor performance of the securities, according to court documents. The credit rating agency has called the suit “meritless.”

abstract: For the last four months, Chinese hackers have persistently attacked The New York Times, infiltrating its computer systems and getting passwords for its reporters and other employees, Nicole Perlroth reports in Thursday’s New York Times.

abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s statement that prosecuting big banks could harm the financial system raises a lot of questions. | Mary Jo White, the nominee to head the S.E.C., goes before the Senate Banking Committee. | Michael S. Dell gave a rare interview about his effort to buy Dell Inc. | Federal regulators accused Illinois of misleading investors about the condition of its public pension system.

abstract: Research shows that in some industries, casual interaction among employees enhances creativity and innovation. Plus, some benefits, like free meals, might actually give workers a tax break.

abstract: Getty Images and Luminate, a company that specializes in making digital images interactive, are working together to embed information about Web sites, Twitter feeds and articles in Getty photographs.

headline: When Is Activism Worth Getting Arrested?
abstract: While no one knows how many environmental activists around the world have run afoul of the law during their protests, the numbers are growing.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include an essay on the way we sign e-mails, an experiment using robots made from toothbrushes and an advice story from the chief of an online real estate company.

headline: Avenue Capital Prepares New Fund for Europe
abstract: The hedge fund run by Marc Lasry is in the process of raising a $500 million fund to invest in distressed European assets, signaling the firm’s continued belief in a long-term recovery for the region.

headline: Scientific Games to Buy WMS Industries for $1.5 Billion
abstract: The Scientific Games Corporation has agreed to buy WMS Industries for $1.5 billion, bolstering its position in the casino and lottery industry.

abstract: The population of illegal immigrants to the United States is changing. After Mexico, where illegal immigration is slowing, comes Central America and Asia.

abstract: JPMorgan Chase is making changes to its policy on Internet-based payday lenders. | John C. Malone is moving to re-enter the cable business. | Federal authorities are scrutinizing Microsoft’s involvement with companies and officials accused of paying bribes overseas. | Bill Gross is auctioning off some rare stamps.

headline: Citigroup Pay Plan Raises the Bar Just a Bit
abstract: Under the new plan, the bank’s target for return on assets is still being set too low, the author contends.

headline: Talk of a Big Merger Gives Office Suppliers’ Stocks a Lift
abstract: Shares of Office Depot and OfficeMax were up significantly in early trading on Tuesday, amid reports that the two were in talks to combine in a stock-for-stock deal.

headline: One Last Pas de Deux for Stars of the Royal Ballet
abstract: Sergei Polunin and Tamara Rojo both left the company last year, setting the ballet world reeling. The chance to see them together once more is leaving Covent Garden audiences breathless.

headline: Temasek Increases Stake in Spanish Energy Concern
abstract: Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund Temasek Holdings said on Monday that it had increased its stake in the Spanish energy company Repsol in a deal worth around $1.3 billion.

abstract: Judge Victor Marrero made it clear that he was troubled that SAC Capital did not have to acknowledge wrongdoing to settle insider-trading accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

abstract: I told one of my managers that I feel good about our prospects for next year, and she reminded me that I say that every year.

abstract: Bank customers will be allowed to stop withdrawals for high-interest payday loans and close their accounts sooner.

abstract: At the South by Southwest Conference, Google gave a demonstration of its Project Glass and showed how some apps would work with the eyewear.

abstract: The oil company, in a proxy fight with the hedge fund Elliott Management, said it would shed its retail and refining arms so that it could focus on exploration and production.

headline: Yahoo’s Next Big Play: South by Southwest
abstract: Yahoo has increased its presence at the annual South by Southwest festival in Texas in hopes of burnishing its image among the tech elite gathering there.

headline: Militant Attack in Srinagar Kills Five Police Officers
abstract: Armed men open fire on a police camp near a school.

headline: Cyprus Shows How Not to Do a Bailout
abstract: The Cyprus crisis shows that, for all the faults with the financial crisis rescues in the United States, the European Union still finds ways to show us how poorly a bailout could be handled.

abstract: The purchase completes a sales process that was expected to take several more years.

headline: C.E.S 2013: Cisco Wants Your Video to Find You
abstract: In the future, the TV shows and movies you want to watch should find you — you shouldn’t have to find them. And you should be able to watch them on any device. That’s the video service Cisco Systems wants to put in your living room.

headline: Getting Your Will and Estate Plans Together
abstract: Bucks readers share tips on getting their wills, powers of attorney, accounts and other estate planning matters in order.

headline: Wal-Mart Introduces Lockers as It Battles Amazon in E-Commerce
abstract: In its competition with Amazon, Walmart is stepping up its offerings in e-commerce and mobile shopping, including the introduction of lockers for picking up items ordered online and a new Web site and mobile app.

headline: Q&A: Checking a Web Site’s Security
abstract: Google Chrome and other browsers can warn you if something does not seem right with a Web site’s security credentials.

headline: Q. & A. on Wall Street’s Untouchables
abstract: “Frontline” investigated why the leaders of Wall Street have escaped prosecution for their role in the country’s financial meltdown. Watch the report on DealBook and read our conversation with the show’s producer, Martin Smith.

headline: Juniper Jumps Into Software Networks
abstract: The second-biggest computer networking company announced its strategy for software defined networks. The specifics aren’t all there, but Juniper is hoping to become something like an enterprise software company, without disturbing its original business of selling high-margin hardware. The industry is changing quickly, but if it doesn’t change too fast, the plan might work.

headline: Drum Roll for a Summer Festival of the New
abstract: Kenneth Branagh was there with the director Rob Ashcroft. The actress Maxine Peake was there. Josie Rourke, the artistic director of London’s Donmar Warehouse, was there. The occasion? The announcement of this year’s Manchester International Festival program by its director, Alex Poots.

headline: Nomura Earnings Rise 13%, but Miss Analysts’ Estimates

abstract: An activist hedge fund and The Related Companies offered to raise their takeover bid for CommonWealth REIT on Wednesday to about $2.26 billion, aiming to put additional pressure on the real estate company.

headline: Facebook App Adds Free Voice Calls. Will Anyone Care?

headline: Alternatives to Dell Deal Come With Too Little Certainty
abstract: Michael S. Dell and Silver Lake Partners have made a low-ball offer for the PC maker. Yet, it’s at a respectable 25 percent premium, and the company’s shares haven’t topped the $13.65-a-share deal price in months, the authors write.

headline: Prominent Prosecutor Is Expected to Join the Private Sector
abstract: Reed Brodsky, the government lawyer who helped secure the insider trading conviction of Raj Rajaratnam, is expected to join the firm of Gibson Dunn & Crutcher.

headline: Picturehouse, Small Film Distributor, Is Returning
abstract: The original Picturehouse, formed in 2005, distributed indie films like “Pan’s Labyrinth” before closing in 2008. Now its founder, Bob Berney, and his wife Jeanne, will try to rebuild it.

headline: Goldman Awards Blankfein $13.3 Million in Stock
abstract: Days after posting a jump in profit, Goldman Sachs said the bank’s chief executive and chairman had been granted restricted stock valued at $13.3 million for 2012, which is expected to bring his total compensation to $21 million.

headline: Hiring Outside Advisers Is as Important as Hiring Employees
abstract: The first question to ask when hiring an outside adviser is, do you need a specialist or a generalist?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Vine Artists and Digital 2013
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include musings on the Steve Jobs action figure (retail: $200), fine art as emoticons on Twitter and security weaknesses in the Emergency Alert System as illustrated by fake zombie attack messages.

headline: Indexation Perils
abstract: Many government benefits and policies are based on the consumer price index, and it might be time to examine those relationships and focus more on wages, an economist writes.

headline: A Marshall McLuhan Approach to Weather Forecasting
abstract: A start-up wants to launch satellites that would gather data to make weather forecasts by studying how signals from GPS satellites are distorted by the atmosphere they pass through.

headline: For Icahn, a Game of Chicken With Dell’s Board
abstract: With his two alternatives to the proposed buyout of Dell, Carl C. Icahn is hoping to make the computer maker’s board blink first.

headline: SAP Steps on the Gas
abstract: SAP, the German business software maker, announced that a fast-growing product called HANA, which radically speeds analysis, will be sold with all of its products. It’s a shot across the bow of both Microsoft and Oracle, which are in their own race to make older products work faster.

abstract: A Congressional investigation could revive questions about the role of senior executives in a $6 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase.

abstract: The Department of Justice and the Patent and Trademark Office issued a joint statement urging that standard patents not be used as weapons — for example, in the smartphone patent wars.

abstract: A minivan with a built-in vacuum, olive oil’s secret may be in its scent, a warning about tax season frauds and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Greek Yogurt Touts Appeal of the ‘Real’ Thing
abstract: Chobani, the Greek yogurt brand, is expanding a marketing campaign called “Go real” into realms that include print and digital advertisements; the brand’s Web site, chobani.com; and social media like Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Vatican Goes ‘Cash Only’ Because of Lack of Money-Laundering Controls
abstract: The Vatican has been struggling for years to shake off its reputation for shady finances. Now, a decision by the Bank of Italy has forced museums and businesses within its walls to stop accepting bank card payments.

headline: The Incomes of Physicians
abstract: The new health care law may help drive down some costs, but it is unlikely to have significant impact on physicians’ incomes, an economist writes.

headline: A ‘Mary Tyler Moore Show’ Reunion, Via Cleveland
abstract: The TV Land sitcom “Hot in Cleveland” will reunite all of the major female stars from one of television’s most beloved comedies, “The Mary Tyler Moore Show.”

headline: ArcelorMittal to Sell Stake in Iron Ore Unit for $1.1 Billion
abstract: The giant steel maker has agreed to sell a 15 percent stake in a Canadian iron ore unit to a consortium of Asian investors that includes Posco of South Korea.

headline: One Delhi Gang Rape Suspect Ruled a Minor
abstract: Maximum sentence three years if suspect is found guilty.

headline: French Communists Abandon Hammer and Sickle
abstract: As France’s once powerful Communist Party met for a congress near Paris, some members were outraged by a decision to drop an iconic symbol of the international proletarian struggle.

abstract: The online betting site Intrade, which allows consumers to bet on world events, announced late on Sunday that it had halted trading and frozen customer accounts after the company said it had discovered potential financial irregularities.

headline: Your Rights in Dealing With Telemarketers
abstract: Even if your number isn’t on the Do Not Call Registry, you can tell a telemarketer to stop calling.

headline: Hillary and the 2016 Presidential Election. Yes, 2016.
abstract: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, speaks with Jim Rutenberg, a Times political correspondent, on the rampant speculation over Hillary Clinton’s political ambitions — and the evidence that suggests “she is.”

headline: Image of the Day: March 8
abstract: A female gymnast performs a stunt in Mumbai on International Women’s Day.

headline: The Extraordinary Trial of Khmer Rouge Leaders
abstract: With Brother No. 2, or Nuon Chea, the former ideologue of the Khmer Rouge, ill and in hospital, an extraordinary trial in Phnom Penh slows again.

headline: Elliott Calls Hess Plan ‘Incomplete’ and Lacking ‘Accountability’
abstract: Elliott Management, the hedge fund leading a proxy fight against Hess, said in a statement that the oil company’s recently unveiled plan to shake itself up did not go far enough to address management problems.

headline: A Kurdish Spring on Many Fronts
abstract: An anticipated truce between Turkey and Kurdish rebels could mark the latest advance for the largest nation in the world without a state of its own.

headline: Deciding Whether to Dip a Toe in the Market
abstract: Bucks readers discuss their investing strategy and their views about the stock market.

abstract: By New Year’s Eve, 65 banks had registered their derivatives business with regulators and turned over heaps of real-time trading data to outside warehouses, fulfilling a centerpiece of the Obama administration’s financial regulatory crackdown.

abstract: Avoiding moral hazard proved to be disastrous when Lehman Brothers failed. Will Cyprus be similar?

headline: U.S. Tech Firms Facing Stronger European Data Protection Measures
abstract: Over the last year, American regulators and technology trade groups have tried to contain an effort by the European Commission to increase data protection regulations for Europeans. That may not be enough to slow the momentum in Europe.

headline: A Potential Potemkin Fight Over Dell
abstract: Blackstone, or even Carl C. Icahn, may succeed with their bids, but it’s just as likely that all the maneuvering won’t bring a better deal for Dell investors, the author contends.

headline: For International Students, College Checklists for March
abstract: College counselors in the United States offer monthly advice for juniors and seniors who want to stay on track during the admissions process.

headline: Backstage to Acquire Sonicbids
abstract: The deal will combine two of the leading sites that help actors and up-and-coming musicians find work.

headline: Start-Up Uses Portal Game as Recruiting Tool
abstract: The tech industry has come up with a lot of wacky ideas for recruiting engineers, but WibiData, a San Francisco start-up that develops big data applications, has come up with a unique gimmick for telegraphing its engineering street cred to job applicants: a custom version of Portal 2, a video game from Valve.

headline: With Set-Aside, Deutsche Bank Cuts 2012 Profit
abstract: The big German bank said its legal expenses related to sour mortgages and rate rigging would require it to reduce its previous 2012 profit total by $517 million.

headline: AT&T and General Motors Will Bring Wireless Data to Cars
abstract: Your smartphone and tablet can already share the same pool of data on your cellphone bill. Next year, you may be able to add a General Motors car to your phone plan as well.

headline: Mario Draghi Takes the E.C.B.’s Message to Spain
abstract: The European Central Bank and its president, Mario Draghi, want to ensure that their voices get heard beyond the financial district of Frankfurt. But their efforts to spread their message more directly to the citizens of Europe have ended up backfiring, at least when it comes to visiting Spain, one of the countries at the center of the Continent’s debt crisis.

headline: Microsoft Attacks Google on Gmail Privacy
abstract: Microsoft plans to unveil a new advertising campaign that will highlight research that shows most people don’t know that Web e-mail providers like Google scan the contents of their messages to deliver personalized ads to them and, when they do find out, they don’t like it.

headline: Hey, What About Men’s Rights?
abstract: It is a myth that Indian society is male-dominated, and a recent anti-rape law is discriminating against men, a group in Pune says.

headline: Image of the Day: Jan. 4
abstract: A self-defense class for girls at a school in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: Witness List Set for Senate Hearing on JPMorgan Trading Loss
abstract: Doug Braunstein, who was the bank’s chief financial officer at the time of the losses, is scheduled to appear, as is Ina Drew. Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief, will not testify.

headline: For Michael Jackson Bio, Trying to Even the Score
abstract: Mr. Jackson’s fans used Amazon to malign a “Untouchable: The Strange Life and Tragic Death of Michael Jackson”, a new book on the singer. But as news of their exploits spread, some people struck back.

headline: In Pursuit of Cohen, One Dead End
abstract: The government’s strategy of relying on lower-level employees to investigate Steven A. Cohen is not without its challenges. | Jack Ma, the founder of Alibaba, is giving up his C.E.O. title but staying on as executive chairman. | Shares of Dell rose on Monday after a report that the company was in talks over a potential buyout. | Thomas Weisel, a legendary banker behind Yahoo’s public offering, has been thrust in the spotlight for backing Lance Armstrong.

headline: Bumps in the Office Supply Merger
abstract: The careful choreography of the Office Depot-OfficeMax merger went awry when the deal was accidentally leaked prematurely. | Anheuser-Busch InBev is in talks to try to resolve antitrust issues with its planned deal with Grupo Modelo. | The New York Times Company plans to sell The Boston Globe and its other properties in New England. | The Carlyle Group announced fourth-quarter results.

headline: Bracing for the Next Political Standoff
abstract: A sense of relief among businesses is tempered by the anticipation of political battles to come. | Sophisticated investors increasingly are wary of big banks. | Al Jazeera is gaining a larger foothold in the United States with a deal for Current TV. | The Avis Budget Group’s deal for Zipcar is a new direction for the company.

headline: Cadwalader Attracts a Top Deal Maker
abstract: James C. Woolery is leaving JPMorgan Chase to join Cadwalader. | The recent spate of deals has come as the stock market hits record levels. | The latest round of financing for Warby Parker attracted two prominent names. | The old Italian bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena has been crippled by 21st-century finance.

abstract: A third of small businesses say there are few or no qualified applicants for open jobs, even though more than 12 million people are looking for work. What gives?

abstract: The investigation of SAC Capital Advisors highlights the challenges of using lower-level workers to build a case against their boss.

headline: Kayaker Aborts Solo Pacific Voyage
abstract: For much of last year, kayaking enthusiasts around the world were keeping tabs on Wave Vidmar, who said he was planning to kayak from California to Hawaii, totally alone and unsupported.

headline: Bookish, New Web Site, Provides Information on Books and Authors
abstract: The site will provide content about books in a literary magazine-like format, with a diverse range of articles. It also has a new book recommendation engine.

abstract: An air show in Bangalore, Karnataka, ahead of the Aero India 2013 aviation exhibition.

headline: Chairman of Barnes & Noble Planning Offer for Its Stores, but Not Nook
abstract: Leonard Riggio, who built Barnes & Noble into a book-selling empire, wants to buy its 689 stores and create a private company that would not have to meet Wall Street’s expectations.

headline: Anschutz Calls Off Sale of Entertainment Arm
abstract: The investment company owned by the billionaire Philip Anschutz has decided to call off efforts to sell the Anschutz Entertainment Group, a sports and live entertainment juggernaut.

headline: Apple Agrees to Settle Lawsuit Over App Purchases by Children
abstract: Apple has agreed to reimburse parents whose children purchased virtual goods in mobile apps without the parents’ knowledge. Apple and the plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed against the company in 2011 last week asked a judge to approve a settlement over such unauthorized “in-app purchases.”

headline: It’s Pensioners on the Side of Hedge Funds Making Their Case Against Argentina
abstract: Several holdouts from a debt swap who are pensioners traveled to New York, a month before an appeals court is to make an important decision on a legal case that has pitted the hedge fund manager Paul E. Singer against the government of Argentina.

headline: Appeals Court Rules for Warner Bros. in Superman Suit
abstract: A federal appeals court in California ruled in favor of Warner Brothers in a long-running legal battle over the copyright ownership of Superman. It was the second ruling in three months favoring Warner and its DC Comics unit over the estates of the character’s co-creators.

headline: Sports Illustrated Lands New Armstrong Interview

abstract: Analysts question growth targets released on Wednesday.

abstract: It is time to look at how men are portrayed in Bollywood.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: Industry Shifts With Dell Deal
abstract: The effects of Dell’s landmark move to go private. Kit Eaton reviews video editing apps. The entrepreneur and inventor James Dyson.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
abstract: The Tang Prize, a new award set up by Taiwanese billionaire Samuel Yin, will pay more than the Nobel Prize, and joins a growing list of prizes in the region as Asian wealth and philanthropy spread.

headline: A Tour Puts a City in Reach and at Arm’s Length
abstract: Ramallah is off-limits to most Israelis, but a new tour, requiring permits from both Israel and the Palestinian Authority, is giving them a glimpse of Palestinian life.

headline: Money Advice for Doctors and Lawyers and the Rest of Us
abstract: Doctors and lawyers are big earners and smart people, but that does not necessarily mean they’re the best financial decision-makers.

headline: A New Channel, FXX, Hopes to Extend the FX Brand
abstract: When it starts in September, FXX will broadcast some sitcoms currently shown on FX, as well as original scripted series — all aimed at viewers 18 to 34.

headline: Abbas Pardons Journalist Sentenced for Insulting Him
abstract: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority pardoned Mamdouh Hamamreh, who officers said portrayed Mr. Abbas as a traitor on Facebook.

headline: New Disney Characters Make It Big in TV’s Preschool Playground
abstract: After a year, Disney Junior, a channel aimed at preschoolers, already has the top three preschool cable programs.

headline: Global Powers Cast Wary Eye as Korean Tension Escalates
abstract: Russia and China watched with concern on Friday as the Pentagon rebuked North Korea over its rising threats toward the United States and South Korea.

headline: In Cyprus, Feeling the Pain of a Bailout
abstract: The reaction of much of the financial world to the Cyprus crisis has been muted, but on the island, the damage and pain are resulting in a rising anger.

headline: Cyberattacks Seem Meant to Destroy, Not Just Disrupt
abstract: Corporate leaders have long feared hacking in service of fraud or spying, but now a new threat has taken hold: attackers, possibly with state support, who seem bent on destruction.

headline: Controls on Capital Come Late to Cyprus
abstract: Cyprus would be better off now had huge amounts of money not flowed into its banks in 2008 and 2009.

headline: As Economy Heats Up, Traffic Backs Up
abstract: The Inrix Gridlock Index monitors driving time by tracking GPS devices and cellphones; a rising index means economic movement.

headline: From Disney, a Video Game Universe on One Platform
abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

headline: In Heinz Takeover, a New Path for Deals
abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

headline: Tell Us: Employer Benefits for Same-Sex Couples
abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

abstract: A case brought by the founders of Dragon Systems was among a spate of legal problems and public relations headaches for Goldman in recent years.

headline: Fund-Raising for Schools, Using Old Class Photos
abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Disappointing Super Bowl Ads, and a Hollywood Outsider Makes His Move
abstract: A critique of the Super Bowl ads finds them wanting; Legendary Entertainment, run by a Hollywood outsider, gets a large piece of the blockbuster movie season; and the FX channel embraces the dark side of storytelling.

headline: ABC Works on an App for Live Streaming Shows to Mobile Devices
abstract: The app, which would stream programming to the phones and tablets of cable and satellite subscribers, could become available to some subscribers this year.

headline: Electronic Arts Chief Resigns
abstract: John Riccitiello, who became chief executive in 2007, fell victim to internal errors and falling sales of traditional video games as consumer tastes changed.

headline: Sectarian Strains Pit Some Iraqis Against Their Own Leaders
abstract: Rafe al-Essawi, until recently Iraq’s finance minister and one of the highest-ranking Sunni politicians, is now on the run from the Shiite-led government.

headline: U.N. Panel to Investigate Human Rights Abuses in North Korea
abstract: The 47-member Human Rights Council was unanimous in adopting a resolution to create a commission to investigate reports of food deprivation, labor camps and torture.

headline: U.S. May Sell Airwaves That Help Broadway Sing
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is considering plans to force the users of cordless microphones to move to a less desirable spot on the nation’s airwaves.

headline: A Strange Computer Promises Great Speed
abstract: Lockheed Martin will make commercial use of quantum computing, which could solve some business and science problems millions of times faster than can be done today.

headline: As Banks in Cyprus Falter, Other Tax Havens Step In
abstract: Cyprus is hardly the only safe harbor for the tax-averse. Switzerland, Luxembourg, Malta and the Caymans are reminding those shaken by events in Cyprus that they remain open for business.

headline: As Market Heats Up, Trading Slips Into Shadows
abstract: More stock trades, about 40 percent on some days, are being conducted outside public exchanges.

headline: Data Storage Player Prepares to Compete Overseas
abstract: Box, a business data storage and management company, is expanding as part of plans for an expected initial public offering in 2014.

headline: Growing Up With a Trust
abstract: In many states, children with trust funds must be given the details about them at age 18, but tutoring about wealth should start much earlier.

abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

headline: French Automakers’ Biggest Problem? French Consumers
abstract: With vehicle sales in France sinking to their lowest in 15 years, consumers’ flagging appetite has posed a significant economic problem for the country.

headline: Nuclear Test Could Open Window on North Korea
abstract: Though nations have urged the North not to conduct the test, American officials say such a blast could yield much-needed insights into the North’s nuclear program.

headline: Quake Leads to Tsunami, but Fears Ebb
abstract: Residents of islands from the South Pacific to Australia were alerted to the possibility of a tsunami after an 8.0-magnitude earthquake off the Solomon Islands, but warnings were called off.

headline: Presidential Aide Freed, Reports Say, as Top Iranian Politicians Trade Accusations
abstract: The release of Saeed Mortazavi, the imprisoned aide to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, marked a new turn in a fight between the president and Iran’s most influential political family.

headline: Tunisia Moves to Contain Fallout After Opposition Figure Is Assassinated
abstract: The prime minister said he would dissolve the Islamist-led government after a politician, Chokri Belaid, was killed and thousands took to the streets in protest.

headline: Mexico: Six Tourists Are Raped in Home Invasion Near Acapulco
abstract: Five armed and masked men broke into a beach house near the port of Acapulco and raped six Spanish tourists, Mexican authorities said.

headline: Immigration Reform Issue: The Effect on the Budget
abstract: Some obstacles may have been overcome, but reform will probably be opposed by those who will view it as a potentially large expansion of welfare.

headline: Trade Group Lawsuit Challenges Olive Oil Labeling
abstract: The North American Olive Oil Association contends that Kangadis Food falsely labeled its Capatriti brand as olive oil when the product is a fat from leftover olive skins and pits.

headline: With a Super Bowl Ad, Scientology Gets a Crowd
abstract: The Church of Scientology’s commercial, alongside pitches for Budweiser, Coca-Cola and Mercedes-Benz, came in the wake of criticism of treatment of church members.

headline: North Korea Covers Tunnel at a Nuclear Site
abstract: After threatening to conduct a nuclear test, North Korea is keeping intelligence analysts guessing when a blast might occur.

headline: Deal Reached for Inquiry on Bombing in Argentina
abstract: Iran and Argentina agreed to start a joint commission to investigate the suicide bombing that killed 85 people at a community center in Buenos Aires in 1994.

headline: French Force and Malians Advancing Into North
abstract: As French and Malian soldiers closed in on the eastern city of Gao, a militant stronghold, the Mali Army’s record of atrocities have raised questions about its fitness to fight with the French.

headline: A Billion-Dollar Club, and Not So Exclusive
abstract: An unexpectedly large number of high-technology start-ups are valued at $1 billion or more.

headline: Target Date Funds at Fidelity Fall Short of Rivals
abstract: Investors have flocked to so-called target date funds, but the retirement products are not as worry-free as the big investment companies advertise.

headline: A Postgame Follow-Up on Super Bowl Commercials
abstract: Reactions were mixed on the effectiveness of the emotional or humorous commercials that were shown during Super Bowl XLVII.

headline: Known for Crime and Poverty, but Working on Its Image
abstract: Marseille, France’s second-largest city, is hoping that its designation as European Capital of Culture for 2013, and its makeover, will lift tourism and its economy.

headline: 4,500 Tons of Evidence of Strike in Seville
abstract: The strike by garbage collectors is entering its second week and threatening to turn into a health safety issue in one of Spain's most touristic cities.

headline: Pirates Seize French-Owned Tanker and Hold 17 Aboard
abstract: The attack was the most serious in a series of recent raids by pirates in the Gulf of Guinea, where patrols are scarce.

headline: Japan Airlines Says 787 Grounding Will Cost It $7.5 Million
abstract: In announcing the forecast loss, the Japanese carrier joins other Dreamliner operators, like All Nippon Airways and United Airlines, in raising possible compensation demands.

headline: U.S. Military Suspends Ban on Afghan Airline
abstract: The American military agreed to give the Afghan government details of its drug smuggling accusations against Kam Air, after days of Afghan criticism.

headline: U.N. Calls on Papua New Guinea to Curb Violence After Burning Death of Woman
abstract: The killing of a woman accused of sorcery is part of a pattern of vigilante attacks in the country, the United Nations human rights office said on Friday.

headline: John E. Karlin, Who Led the Way to All-Digit Dialing, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Karlin, a Bell Labs industrial research psychologist, was also instrumental in the shortening of telephone cords and the creation of rectangular keypads for touch-tone models.

headline: Heading for Retirement on Autopilot
abstract: An increasingly widespread type of 401(k) plan includes features like automatic enrollment — unless an employee chooses to opt out — and automatic contribution increases.

headline: Battling College Costs, a Paycheck at a Time
abstract: The modern realities of soaring tuition and other expenses are testing, but not defeating, the tradition of working one’s way through school.

headline: Amid a Bloody War, Syrian Videos Show a Glimpse of Fun
abstract: Two videos that show Syrian soldiers and rebels dancing and singing have provoked sharply different political reactions.

headline: Demonstrators Attack Allies of Georgian President, Injuring at Least 5
abstract: At least five lawmakers from the party of President Mikheil Saakashvili were reported injured after an angry crowd of protesters attacked in Tbilisi.

headline: Something Wise From a Talkative Seatmate
abstract: Elana Drell-Szyfer, chief executive of Ahava North America, found herself sitting next to an 80-year-old Catholic nun on a flight to Israel.

headline: Zen Groups Distressed by Accusations Against Teacher
abstract: An independent council of Zen leaders has said that the Buddhist teacher Joshu Sasaki sexually harassed female students.

headline: Squeezing Frequent Fliers Is a Likely Merger Outcome
abstract: If American Airlines and US Airways merge, the number of available award seats is likely to decrease.

headline: China Looms Over Response to Nuclear Test by North Korea
abstract: China will almost certainly join the United States in supporting tougher sanctions for Pyongyang over Tuesday’s  test, accompanied by sterner reprimands from Beijing.

headline: Merck Replaces Its Research Chief
abstract: Dr. Roger M. Perlmutter, the former research head of Amgen, will replace Peter S. Kim, who is retiring after a number of successes and some recent disappointments.

headline: U.N. Starts Talks to Free Peacekeepers Held by Syria Rebels
abstract: It was not clear when 21 Filipino captives, seized on Wednesday in the Golan Heights, might be set free, but the authorities in Manila said they had not been harmed.

headline: American Won’t Join South Korea Cabinet
abstract: A South Korean-born American entrepreneur, nominated to be minister of education, science and technology, withdrew on Monday, blaming political gridlock.

headline: Kerry Says Syrian Opposition Can Handle Military Aid
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry, after meeting with the Saudi foreign minister, also criticized Iran and Russia for helping arm the Assad government.

headline: Massacre of Syrian Soldiers in Iraq Raises Risk of Widening Conflict
abstract: More than 40 Syrian soldiers who had sought temporary safety in Iraq were killed on Monday in an ambush, in the most serious spillover of violence into Iraq since the Syrian conflict began.

headline: Recovery in U.S. Is Lifting Profits, but Not Adding Jobs
abstract: Experts estimate so-called budget sequestration could cost the country about 700,000 jobs, but Wall Street doesn’t expect the cuts to substantially alter corporate profits or threaten stock markets.

headline: A Jester No More, Italy’s Gadfly of Politics Reflects a Movement
abstract: After a successful showing in last week’s election, Beppe Grillo, a comedian turned activist, is being courted by Italy’s traditional political players, with whom he has refused to play ball.

headline: Nominee for Japan’s Central Bank Vows Aggressive Action
abstract: The candidate, Haruhiko Kuroda of the Asian Development Bank, told a confirmation hearing he would do “whatever it takes” to counter the country’s deflation.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.

headline: U.S. and Russia Team Up in Bid to Aid Polar Bears
abstract: The countries are the main allies pushing for greater protection for the bears under a global treaty on endangered species, which is being reviewed at a conference in Bangkok.

abstract: Disney Interactive Studios unveiled a new video game initiative, Disney Infinity, where players have the opportunity to create experiences starring characters from the company’s most popular franchises.

abstract: Teaming up with private equity might turn out to be a combination that works as well as ketchup on a Whopper.

abstract: We are continuing to collect information on what domestic partner benefits companies offer to their gay and lesbian employees..

abstract: A case brought by the founders of Dragon Systems was among a spate of legal problems and public relations headaches for Goldman in recent years.

abstract: A new Web service aims to give schools a new way to raise funds, using their old photos.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Disappointing Super Bowl Ads, and a Hollywood Outsider Makes His Move
abstract: A critique of the Super Bowl ads finds them wanting; Legendary Entertainment, run by a Hollywood outsider, gets a large piece of the blockbuster movie season; and the FX channel embraces the dark side of storytelling.

abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.

headline: Syria Opposition Leaders Delay Trip to Washington
abstract: Moaz al-Khatib, the leader of the Syrian Opposition Council, may be building up his moderate coalition.

headline: Berlusconi Gets One-Year Sentence Over Wiretapping Case
abstract: The verdict against Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister, is expected to weaken his position as talks begin on forming a coalition government.

headline: In Parts of Syria, Lack of Assistance ‘Is a Catastrophe’
abstract: The vast majority of foreign aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad while the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible.

headline: Setback to Boeing’s Hopes for Longer Range for 787
abstract: Because of recent incidents with the jet’s battery, an advanced feature allowing for new flight paths may not receive approval for months, which could dilute the jet’s appeal.

headline: Man Who Helped Image of Wal-Mart Steps Down
abstract: Leslie Dach, who is credited with polishing the company’s image through energy conservation, environmentally friendly packaging and philanthropy, is resigning after almost seven years.

headline: Online Emotions, in Hundreds of New Flavors
abstract: Emoji and now online “stickers” have not been as popular in the United States as in other parts of the world. But some new American companies are trying to change that.

headline: Iraq: Security Forces Open Fire on Sunni Demonstrators in North
abstract: Security forces fired on stone-throwing Sunni demonstrators in the northern city of Mosul on Friday, killing one and wounding five, according to Iraqi officials.

headline: Germany: Airport Project Reorganized
abstract: A manager who turned around Germany’s national railway and second largest airline took over the company behind the construction of Berlin’s new international airport on Friday.

headline: Roadside Bomb Kills 3 Soldiers in Pakistan Tribal District
abstract: The blast struck a military convoy 20 miles east of Parachinar, the capital of the Kurram tribal district, said a military official who declined to be named.

headline: Airport Lounge Perks Become a Priority
abstract: The competitive environment for premium travelers is heating up.

headline: Iglo and Birds Eye Pull Meals After Finding Horse Meat
abstract: The company that owns Iglo and Birds Eye brands withdrew a dozen types of prepared meals from stores in four European countries after finding traces of horse meat.

headline: Conservative Is Elected President in Cyprus
abstract: The victor, Nicos Anastasiades, now faces crucial negotiations with international lenders over a bailout for his financially ailing nation.

headline: Japan and United States Reaffirm Their Close Ties
abstract: President Obama and Japan’s new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, met at the White House on Friday to discuss their mutual interests in curbing North Korea’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: North Korea Threatens U.S. Over Joint Military Drill
abstract: North Korea warned that if the United States pressed ahead with joint military exercises with South Korea it could set off a war in which American forces would “meet a miserable destruction.”

headline: Scandals and Intrigue Heat Up at Vatican Ahead of Papal Conclave
abstract: The Vatican called recent speculative reports alleging scandal in the Church “deplorable” as cardinals from around the world arrived for a conclave to elect a new pope.

headline: Morsi Moves Election Day in Egypt to Avoid Holiday Conflict
abstract: President Mohamed Morsi changed the dates for the parliamentary elections to avoid conflict with the Coptic Christian celebrations of Palm Sunday and Easter.

headline: Chinese City Reports Second Bird Flu Fatality
abstract: A 31-year-old man who had contracted the deadly H5N1 bird flu died of organ failure in the south-central Chinese city of Guiyang.

headline: For Stocks, an Upturn Is Battered by Doubts
abstract: After looking ready to rocket past milestone levels just a few weeks ago, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is coming out of its first negative week of 2013.

headline: Benedict XVI to Be Known as Emeritus in Retirement
abstract: The Vatican spokesman, Rev. Federico Lombardi, told reporters that the pope would dress in a simple white cassock and no longer wear the papal red shoes.

headline: Treasury Pick Tries to Cast His History as Right for the Job
abstract: Jacob Lew, who faces a Senate panel on Tuesday, is expected to be confirmed as Treasury secretary despite questions about his finances and payment for past work.
